Every event in the SLEE has an event type.
The SLEE specification defines a number of Facilites that may be used by SBB components.  These Facilities include the Timer Facility, the Trace Facility, and the Alarm Facility.
Each Activity Context has a name and a type.
Since an SBB entity may only be created once, it only has a single parent.
The SLEE will only create instances of root SBBs, known as root SBB entities.
An SBB entity belongs to exactly one SBB entity tree.

For example, the SLEE may instatiate a root CallBlockingAndForwarding SBB entity to handle a single call.  This SBB entity may subsequently create zero or more children CallBlockingSBB or CallForwardingSBB entities to help it handle the call.  This SBB entity tree has one root CallBlockingAndForwarding SBB entity and zero or more directed edges from the root SBB entity to its child CallBlocking SBB and CallForwarding SBB entities.
An SBB entity sub-tree is a tree whose root is a decscendent of a root SBB entity.
An event is delivered in order to each SBB entity that is interested in receiving the event.
A parent SBB entity always receives the same event before its child SBB entities.
The event delivery priority of an SBB entity determines the order that sibling SBB entities receive the event.

The parent SBB specifies a default event delivery priority for each child relation.  When a parent SBB entity creates a child SBB entity, the SLEE assigns the default event delivery priority specified by the child relation to the child SBB entity.
An SBB entity can be removed by invoking the remove method on the SbbLocalObject interface or via the ChildRelationObject interface.
Only the immediate parent of a child SBB entity can invoke a method t o remove the child SBB enity.

When the SLEE removes a sub-tree, it performs a pre-order traversal of the sub-tree to delete the SBB entities in the sub-tree.  It deletes the parent SBB entity before it deletes the child SBB entities.
The SLEE does not specify the order in which sibling SBB entities are deleted.
When the SLEE removes an SBB entity, the SLEE detaches the SBB entity from all Activity Contexts (see Section 7.3.3).
... and the SLEE invokes the appropriate life cycle methods (see Section 6.3) on any SBB objects that cache the SBB entity's state.
... and the SLEE detaches the SBB entity from all Activity Contexts.

When an SBB object is assigned to represent an SBB entity, the SBB object is in the Ready state (see Section 6.3).  It can receive and fire events, receive synchronous method invocations, and access and update the persistent state of the SBB entity.
Each SBB has an SBB local interface.

An SBB object is only allowed to invoke SBB local objects that represent SBB entities in the same SBB entity tree.  The execution behaviour of the SLEE is undefined if an SBB object attempts to invoke an SBB local object that represents an SBB entity that is not in the same SBB entity tree.
It [An Activity Context] does not have a visible Java API.
There is a one to one relationship between an Activity object and an Activity Context.
These SBB entities can read and modify attributes stored in the Activity Context.
An Activity Context is also an event channel that accepts events fired on the Activity Context and distributes these events to the SBB entities attached to the Activity Context.
An SBB entity can invoke other SBB entities in an asynchronous manner by firing events on the Activity Context.
An SBB entity may be attached to one or more Activity Contexts.
An SBB entity can only receive events fired on Activity Contexts that it is attached to.

The SLEE does not count the number of times an SBB entity is attached or detached from an Activity Context.  The SBB entity is either attached to the Activity Context or not.  Attaching multiple times consecutively is the same thing as attaching once and detaching multiple times is the same as detaching once.
When a new root SBB entity is created to process its initial event, the SLEE attaches the new root SBB entity to the Activity Context on which the initial event was fired (see Section 8.5).
After the underlying Activity object of an Activity Context ends, the SLEE detaches SBB entities attached to the Activity Context (see Section 7.3.3).
Before the SLEE removes an SBB entity as part of a cascading-removal of an SBB entity sub-tree, the SLEE detaches the SBB entity from all Activity Contexts.
An SBB entity may detach itself from an Activity Context if it no longer wants to receive events fired on that Activity Context.

An SBB entity may explicitly attach another SBB entity to an Activity Context. This functionality allows the delegation of all or some processing of events fired on the Activity Context to another SBB entity.

An SBB entity may attach itself to the Activity Context of a new Activity object that it has created.  This allows the SBB entity to receive events fired on the Activity Context by the newly created Activity object.
The SLEE uses the attachment count mechanism to remove SBB entity trees that are no langer attached to any Activity Contexts and hence will no longer be receiving events.

The SLEE maintains an implicit attachment count for each SBB entity.The attachment count of an SBB entity is the total number of SBB entity to Activity Context attachments that the SBB entity and its descendent SBB entities have.

SBB entities of a parent SBB may receive child not attached callbacks if the SBB implements a child not attached method in the SBB abstract class and identifies this method as the child not attached method in the deployment descriptor of the parent SBB.
When an Activity Context's Activity object ends, the SLEE detaches all SBB entities attached to the Activity Context (see Section 7.3.3).
In a well-behaved system, Activity objects should end after a reasonable finite amount of time.
Eventually, the attachment count of the root SBB entity will reach zero.
If the SLEE finds the root SBB entity's attachment count to be zero after an invocation (such as delivering an event), the SLEE reclaims the SBB entity tree by removing the root SBB entity.
column14: In the root SBB's event handler detach the root from all ActivityContexts.  Verify that sbbRemoved() is called for this SBB and its children.

column8: Removing the root SBB entity initiates a cascading removal operation that also removes all the descendent SBB entities (see Section 2.2.6).
column14: As above.

column8: As t he Activity objects end in the SLEE, the SLEE detaches SBB entities from these Activity Contexts.  Eventually, the attachment count of a child SBB entity of a parent SBB entity will decrement to zero.  If the parent SBB entity has a child not attached callback method, then the SLEE invokes this method with an SBB local object as the only argument.  This SBB local object represents the child SBB entity that is no longer attached.
Then, it [implementation of the child not attached method] will remove the sub-tree rooted at the child SBB entity as described in Section 2.2.6.
Detach operations are transactional (see Chapter 9 for a more detailed discussions on transactions).

The attachment count of an SBB entity that will have its child not attached method invoked is not decremented until after the child not attached method has been invoked.  This ensures that only one child not attached method will be invoked at any one time ofr each detach operation, and the child not attached callbacks are invoked on descendents before child not attached callbacks are invoked on ancestors.

When there are multiple detach operations, there may be multiple valid callback orders for child not attached callbacks.  A callback order is valid if the semantics specified in the previous paragraph are maintained.
An SBB entity interacts with an Activity Context through an Activity Context Interface object.
The Activity Context Interface object provides an Activity Context with a visible Java API that can be invoked.
Through an Activity Context Interface object, an SBB can get access to the underlying Activity object of an Activity Context.
The SBB Activity Context Interface interface provides a type-safe mechanism for accessing shareable attributes stored in Activity Contexts.
A profile table contains zero or more Profiles that conform to the same schema.

The SLEE specification includes ... A Resource Info Profile Specification.  This specifies the schema for all Resource Info Profile Tables and the interfaces used to provision and access a Profile in one of these Profile Tables.

The SLEE specification includes ... A generic Address Profile Specification.  This specifies the schema for all generic Address Profile Tables and the interfaces used to provision and access a Profile in one of these generic Address Profile Tables.
In addition to these SLEE-defined Profile Specifications, SBB Developers can define custom Profile Specifications.
The SLEE will assign the default event delivery priority of the child relation to root SBB enitites created by the SLEE for this Service (see Figure 2).
To define a Service, the Administrator provides a Service deployment descriptor element that provides ... a globally unique name of the Service.
To define a Service, the Administrator provides a Service deployment descriptor element that provides ... a reference to a root SBB.
To define a Service, the Administrator provides a Service deployment descriptor element that provides ... an optional reference to a Resource Info Profile Table.
To define a Service, the Administrator provides a Service deployment descriptor element that provides ... an optional reference to an Address Profile Table.
A Service can be in one of the following three operational states: Inactive, Active and Stopping.
Inactive: ... root SBB entities of the Service's root SBB will not be created to process events.
Active: The SLEE will create root SBB entities of the Service's root SBB to receive initial events and invoke SBB entities in the SBB entity trees of the Service.
Stopping: The SLEE is waiting for the SBB entities in these SBB entity trees to complete processing so they can be reclaimed.
An SBB entity has completed processing and can be reclaimed when it and all of its child SBB entities are no longer attached to any Activity Context (see Section 7.3.3).
The following steps describe the life cycle of a Service:
A Service enters the Inactive state when the Service is installed successfully into the SLEE.
A Service enters the Active state from the Inactive state when the Service is activated.
At this point, the SLEE may start a Service Activity for the Service, and fire a Service Started Event on this Activity, as described in Section  8.7.
A Service enters the Stopping state from the Active state when the Service is deactivated.
At this point, the SLEE ends the Activity associated with the Service, if it exists (see Section 8.7.2) and fires an Activity End Event on this Activity.

SBB entities belonging to the Service that require clean-up when the Service is deactivated should listen to this event and terminate their processing quickly but gracefully when this event is received.
Optionally, after some SLEE implementation determined time, the SLEE may also forcefully remove the outstanding SBB entity trees of the Service.
The SLEE moves a Service to the Inactive state from the Stopping state spontaneously when all outstanding SBB entity trees of the Service complete their processing.

The operational state of a Service is persistent, i.e. The SLEE remembers the last state the Service is in.  If the SLEE is shut down and then restarted, the SLEE restores these Services to their previous operational state.
column10: The current SLEE TCK architecture does not support SLEE shutdown within tests.

column8: The SLEE specification defines the external management interfaces that may be used by Administrators to manage the SLEE and the Services running in the SLEE.
Management Interface: Start and stop the SLEE.
Management Interface: Install and uninstall a deployable unit.
Management Interface: Start and stop a service.
Management Interface: Create and delete a Profile Table.
Management Interface: Add, remove, access and modify a Profile in a Profile Table.
Management Interface: Register and deregister for alarm notifications.
Management Interface: Register and deregister for trace notifications.
Management Interface: Obtain and reset usage counters and statistics.
The Service Deployer should know which Services have been or will be deployed into the SLEE and the external resources that are plugged into the SLEE.
The Service Deployer creates a deployment descriptor element  for each Service.
In addition, the Service specifies the default event delivery priority of the Service's root SBB.
An SBB's component identity uniquely identifies an SBB component.
An SBB's component identity does not identify any particular SBB entity.
An SBB's name, vendor, and version, as defined by the sbb-name, sbb-vendor, and sbb-version elements in the SBB's deployment descriptor specify the component identity of an SBB.
Each SBB Activity Context Interface specifies the attributes that the SBB is willing to share with other SBBs.
By default, these attributes can be shared among SBB entities of the same SBB component.

column8: However, they are not accessible by SBB entities of other SBBs to avoid unintentional sharing resulting from two SBBs developed independently selecting the same attribute name f or two semantically distinct attributes.

column8: The SBB local interface must extend the javax.slee.SbbLocalInterface interface.
If the SBB Developer does not specify an SBB local interface, the SLEE supplies the generic SbbLocalObject interface.
This SbbLocalObject interface declares the remove method used by an SBB entity to remove another SBB entity.
The SBB abstract class is mandatory.
It implements the javax.slee.Sbb interface.
The SLEE invokes one of these life cycle callback methods when an SBB object transitions from one life cycle state to another life cycle state (see Section 6.2).
The SLEE invokes [the sbbExceptionThrown()] method after a SLEE originated invocation of a transactional method of the SBB object returns by throwing a RuntimeException.
The SLEE invokes this method (sbbRolledBack) after a transaction that was used to invoke a transactional method of the SBB abstract class has been rolled back.
The SLEE implements these abstract methods when the SBB is deployed: Fire event methods (see Section 8.4.1)
The SLEE implements these abstract methods when the SBB is deployed: CMP field get and set accessor methods (see Section 6.5).
The SLEE implements these abstract methods when the SBB is deployed: Get child relation methods (see Section 6.8).
The SLEE implements these abstract methods when the SBB is deployed: Get Profile CMP methods (see Section 6.7).

Get SBB Usage Parameter methods (see Section 9.4.1). The SBB Developer may declare abstract get SBB Usage Parameter methods used by the SBB to access objects that implement the SBB Usage Parameter interface of the SBB. Each of these objects represents a set of usage parameters that the SBB may manipulate (see Section 9.2).
The SLEE implements these abstract methods when the SBB is deployed: SBB Activity Context Interface narrow method (see Section 7.7.2).
The SBB Activity Context Interface interface must extend the generic ActivityContextInterface interface.

If the SBB does not define an SBB Activity Context Interface interface, it interacts with Activity Context through objects that implement the generic ActivityContextInterface interface that is defined by the SLEE specification.
The generic ActivityContextInterface interface defines a method that provides access to the underlying Activity object of an Activity Context.

If the SBB Developer declares an SBB Activity Context Interface interface, the SBB Developer should also declare an SBB Activity Context Interface interface narrow method to get access to objects that implement the SBB Activity Context Interface interface.
The SBB Developer may optionally provide an SBB Usage Parameters interface.
The SBB declares the names and types of the usage parameters relevant to this SBB in the SBB Usage Parameters interface by declaring the methods used to manipulate these usage parameters.
There are two types of usage parameters: counter-type and sample-type.
An SBB can increment and decrement a counter-type usage parameter,
column12: Cases covered:  increments/decrements: Long.MIN_VALUE,Long.MIN_VALUE+1,-10,-1,0,1,10,Long.MAX_VALUE-1,Long.MAX_VALUE Counter changes: up from 0;down from 0;cross 0 upwards;cross 0 downwards;        upwards from positive;downwards from positive;    upwards from negative;downwards from negative

column8: while a sample-type usage parameter accumulates data samples.
If the SBB Developer provides a SBB Usage Parameter interface, the SBB Developer declares the following abstract methods in the SBB Usage Parameter interface:

Increment methods:  The SBB Developer declares  increment methods to declare the presence of and to update counter-type usage parameters.  The SLEE derives the names of each usage parameter name from the name of each increment method.

Sample methods:  The SBB Developer declares a sample method to declare the presence of and to add samples to sample-type usage parameters.  The SLEE derives the name of each usage parameter name from the name of each sample method.
This interface is optional.  If the SBB does not require any usage parameters, the SBB Developer does not have to provide an SBB Usage Parameters interface.

If the SBB Developer declares an SBB Usage Parameters interface, the SBB Developer should also declare (in the SBB abstract class) at least one of the get SBB Usage Parameter methods to get access to objects that implement the SBB Usage Parameters interface.
The SLEE specification recommends the following naming convention for the interfaces and classes of an SBB component: <name>Sbb, <name>SbbActivityContextInterface, <name>SbbLocalObject.
An SBB deployment descriptor contains an sbb element.
The sbb element contains an optional description element.
The sbb element contains an sbb-name, sbb-vendor and sbb-version element.
The sbb element contains an sbb-alias element.
The sbb element contains zero or more sbb-ref elements.
Each SBB referenced by the SBB of the enclosing sbb element must be identified by an sbb-ref element.
The sbb-ref element contains an optional description element.
The sbb-ref element contains an sbb-name element, an sbb-vendor element and an sbb-version element.
These elements uniquely identify the referenced SBB component and must match exactly the corresponding sbb-name, sbb-vendor and sbb-version elements specified in the referenced SBB's sbb element.
The sbb-ref element contains an sbb-alias element.
The sbb element contains zero or more profile-spec-ref elements.
Each Profile Specification used by the SBB must be identified by a profile-spec-ref element.
A profile-spec-ref element contains an optional description element.
A profile-spec-ref element contains a profile-spec name element, a profile-spec-vendor element and a profile-spec-version element.

These elements uniquely identify the Profile Specification, and must match exactly the corresponding profile-spec-name, profile-spec-vendor and profile-spec-version elements specified in the referenced Profile Specification's profile-spec element.
A profile-spec-ref element contains a profile-spec-alias element.
The sbb element contains an sbb-classes element.
The sbb-classes element contains an optional description element.
The sbb-classes element contains an sbb-abstract-class element.
The sbb-abstract-class element contains a reentrant attribute.
If this attribute is not specified, the default value is "False".
The sbb-abstract-class element contains an optional description element.
The sbb-abstract-class element contains an sbb-abstract-class-name element.
The sbb-abstract-class element contains zero or more cmp-field elements.
Each CMP field defined in the SBB abstract class must be identified by a cmp-field element.
The cmp-field element contains an optional description element.
The cmp-field element contains a cmp-field-name element.
The cmp-field element contains an sbb-alias-ref element.

This optional element references an SBB by its sbb-alias that is specified within the same sbb element. When this element is present, only null and references to SBB entities of the SBB identified by this element can be stored in the CMP field. If the Java type of the CMP field is a SBB local interface (i.e., SbbLocalObject, or a type derived from SbbLocalObject), then this element must be present.
The sbb-abstract-class element contains zero or more get-child-relation-method elements.
Each get child relation method declared in the SBB abstract class must be identified by a get-child-relation-method element.
The get-child-relation-method element contains an optional description element.
The get-child-relation-method element contains an sbb-alias-ref element.
The get-child-relation-method element contains a get-child-relation-method-name element.
The get-child-relation-method element contains a mandatory default-priority element.
The sbb-abstract class element contains a child-not-attached-callback-method-name element.
The sbb-abstract-class element contains zero or more get-profile-cmp-method elements.
Each get Profile CMP method declared in the SBB abstract class must be identified by a get-profile-cmp-method element.
Each get-profile-cmp-method element contains an optional description element.
Each get-profile-cmp-method element contains a profile-spec-alias-ref element.
Each get-profile-cmp-method element contains a get-profile-cmp-method-name element.
The sbb-abstract-class element contains a get-sbb-usage-parameter-method element.

This is an optional element. This element must not be present if the sbb-usage-parameter-interface element is not present. If the SBB abstract class declares one or more methods used to get objects that implement the SBB Usage Parameter interface, then this element must be present.
The get-sbb-usage-parameter-method element contains a description element.
The get-sbb-usage-parameter-method element contains a get-sbb-usage-parameter-method-name element.
This element specifies the name of the methods used to get objects that implement the SBB Usage Parameter interface.
The sbb-classes element contains an sbb-local-interface element.
The sbb-local-interface element contains an optional description element.
The sbb-local-interface element contains an sbb-local-interface-name element.
The sbb-classes element contains an sbb-activity-context-interface element.
The sbb-activity-context-interface element contains an optional description element.
The sbb-activity-context-interface element contains an sbb-activity-context-interface-name element.
The sbb-classes element contains an sbb-usage-parameter-interface element.
This element is optional. If the SBB defines an SBB Usage Parameters interface, this element identifies the SBB Usage Parameters interface. It contains the following sub-elements:
The sbb-usage-parameter-interface contains an optional description element.
The sbb-usage-parameter-interface element contains an sbb-usage-parameter-interface-name element.
The sbb-element contains an address-profile-spec-alias-ref element.
The sbb-element contains zero or more event elements.
Each event type that the SBB may receive or fire must have on event element (see Section 8.1).
An event element contains an initial-event attribute.
An event element contains an event-direction attribute.
The value of the event-direction attribute must be "Fire", "Receive" or "FireAndReceive".
If initial-event is true, then event-direction must be either "Receive" or "FireAndReceive".
An event element contains a mask-on-attach attribute.
An event element contains an optional description element.
An event element contains an event-type-ref element.
An event-type-ref element contains an event-type-name element, an event-type-vendor element, and an event-type version element.
These elements uniquely identify an event type declared in an event-definition element specified in another deployment descriptor.
column10: The uniqueness is tested by 1539

column8: An event element contains an event-name element.
An event element contains zero or more initial-event-select elements.
An initial-event-select element has a variable attribute.
The value of the variable attribute can be one of "ActivityContext", "AddressProfile", "Address", "EventType" or "Event".
An event element contains an initial-event-selector-method-name element.
The initial-event-selector-method-name element is only meaningful if initial-event is true.
An event element contains an event-resource-option element.
The sbb-element contains zero or more activity-context-attribute-alias elements.
The activity-context-attribute-alias element contains an optional description element.
The activity-context-attribute-alias element contains an attribute-alias-name element.

The attribute-alias-name is globally scoped.  If two or more activity-context-attribute-alias elements specify the same attribute-alias-name, all the attributes specified by their sbb-activity-context-attribute elements are aliased.

column8: The activity-context-attribute-alias contains one or more sbb-activity-context-attribute elements.
The sbb-activity-context-attribute element contains an sbb-alias-ref element.
The sbb-activity-context-attribute element contains an sbb-activity-context-attribute-name element.
The sbb-element contains zero or more usage-parameter elements (see Section 12.5).
The usage-parameter element contains an optional description element.
The usage-parameter element contains an env-entry-name element.
The usage-parameter element contains an env-entry-value element.
The usage-parameter element contains an env-entry-type element.
The sbb-element contains zero or more resource-adaptor-type-binding elements.
The resource-adaptor-type-binding element contains an optional description element.
The resource-adaptor-type-binding element contains a resource-adaptor-type-ref element.
The resource-adaptor-type-ref element contais a resource-adaptor-type-name element, a resource-adaptor-type-vendor element, and a resource-adaptor-version-element.

These elements uniquely identify the resource adaptor type, and must match exactly the corresponding resource-adaptor-type-name, resource-adaptor-type-vendor, and resource-adaptor-type-version elements specified in the resource adaptor type's resource-adaptor-type element.
The resource-adaptor-type-binding element contains an activity-context-interface-factory-name element.
The resource-adaptor-type-binding element contains zero or more resource-adaptor-entity-binding elements.
Each resource-adaptor-entity-binding element contains an optional description element.
Each resource-adaptor-entity-binding element contains a resource-adaptor-object-name element.
Each resource-adaptor-entity-binding element contains a resource-adaptor-entity-link element.

The identified resource adaptor entity must be an instance of a resource adaptor whose resource adaptor type is specified by the resource-adaptor-type-ref sub-element of the enclosing resource-adaptor-type-binding element.
The sbb-element contains zero or more ejb-ref elements.
Each ejb-ref element contains an optional description element.
Each ejb-ref element contains an ejb-ref-name element.
Each ejb-ref element contains an ejb-ref-type element.
Each ejb-ref element contains a home element.
Each ejb-ref element contains a remote element.
Each ejb-ref element contains an ejb-link element.

To ease distribution and deployable unit assembly, the SLEE specification recommends thaht the SBB Developer distribute these files using an SBB jar file that can be incorporated into a deployable unit.
The SBB jar file contains the SBB's Java classes and deployment descriptor.
The SBB jar file must include an SBB jar deployment descriptor.
The SBB jar deployment descriptor is stored with the name META-INF/sbb-jar.xml.
The root element of the SBB jar deployment descriptor is an sbb-jar element.
The sbb-jar element contains an optional description element.
The sbb-jar element contains one or more sbb elements.
The SBB jar file must include class files of the SBBs specified by the sbb elements of the sbb-jar element.
The SBB jar file must contain, either by inclusion or by reference the class files of each SBB.

The SBB jar file must also contain, either by inclusion or by reference, the class files for all the classes and interfaces that the SBB's classes and interfaces depend on, except J2SE classes, SLEE classes, classes included in the SBB jar files of referenced SBBs of the SBBs, classes included in the event jar files of the event types referenced by the SBBs, classes included in the Profile Specification jar files of the Profile Specifications referenced by the SBBs, classes included in the resource adaptor type jar files referenced by the SBBs.  This includes their superclasses and superinterfaces, dependent classes, and the classes and interfaces used as method parameters, results and exceptions.
Each custom event type must have an event definition deployment descriptor.
Each event definition deployment descriptor contains an event-definition element.
Each event-definition element contains an optional descripton element.
Each event-definition element contains an event-type-name-element, an event-type-vendor element, and an event-type-version element.
These elements uniquely identify the event type.
column10: The uniqueness is tested by 1539

column8: Each event-definition element contains an event-class-name element. This element identifies the Java class associated with the event type.
To ease distribution and deployable unit assembly, the SLEE specification recommends that the SBB Developer distribute these files in an event jar file.
The event jar file includes an event jar deployment descriptor.
The event jar deployment descriptor is stored with the name META-IN-event-jar.xml in the event jar file.
The root element of the event jar deployment descriptor is an event-jar element.
The event-jar element contains an optional description element.
The event -jar element contains one or more event-definition elements.
The event jar file includes class files of the event types specified by the event-definition elements of the event-jar element.
The event jar file must contain, either by inclusion or by reference, the class file of the event class.

The event jar file must also contain, either by inclusion or by reference, the class files for all the classes and interfaces that the event class depends on, except J2SE classes and SLEE classes.  This includes their superclasses and superinterfaces, dependent classes, and the classes and interfaces used as method parameters, results, and exceptions.
The SBB Developer declares Profile attribute get and set methods in their Profile CMP interface.
Each Profile Specification must have a Profile Specification deployment descriptor.
A Profile Specification deployment descriptor contains a profile-spec element.
Each profile-spec element contains an optional description element.
Each profile-spec element contains a profile-spec-name element, profile-spec-vendor element and a profile-spec-version element.
These elements uniquely identify a Profile Specification.
column10: The uniqueness is tested by 1540

column8: Each profile-spec element contains a profile-classes element.
Each profile-classes element contains an optional description element.
Each profile-classes element contains a profile-cmp-interface-name element.
Each profile-classes contains a profile-management-interface-name element.
Each profile-classes contains a profile-management-abstract-class-name element.
Each profile-spec element contains zero or more profile-index elements.
The profile-index element contains a unique attribute.
If unspecified, the default value for the unique attribute is "False".
The null value is exempt from these uniqueness constraints and may appear multiple times as a value of this attribute in multiple Profiles within the Profile Table.
Each profile-spec element contains a profile-hint element.
The profile-hint element contains the single-profile attribute.
If unspecified, the default value for the single-profile attribute is "False".
The SLEE recommends naming convention: Profile CMP Interface => <name>ProfileCMP.
The SLEE recommends naming convention: Profile Management interface => <name>ProfileManagement.
The SLEE recommends naming convention: Profile Management abstract class => <name>ProfileManagementImpl.

To ease distribution and deployable unit assembly, the SLEE specification recommends thaht the SBB Developer distribute these files using a Profile Specification jar file that can be incorporated into a deployable unit.
The Profile Specification jar file includes the Profile Specification jar deployment descriptor.
The Profile Specification jar deployment descriptor is stored with the name META-INF/profile-spec-jar.xml in the Profile Specification jar file.
The root element of the Profile Specification jar deployment descriptor is a profile-spec-jar element.
The profile-spec-jar element contains an optional description element.
The profile-spec-jar element contains one or more profile-spec elements.
The Profile Specification jar file includes the class files of the Profile Specifications specified by the profile-spec elements of the profile-spec-jar element.
The Profile Specification jar file must contain, either by inclusion or by reference, the class files of each Profile Specification.

The Profile Specification jar file must also contain, either by inclusion or by reference, the class files for all the classes and interfaces that the Profile Specification's classes and interfaces depend on, except J3SE classes and SLEE classes.  This includes their superclasses and superinterfaces, dependent classes, and the classes and interfaces used as method parameters, results and exceptions.
A Service deployment descriptor contains a service element.
The service element contains an optional description element.
The service element contains a service-name element, a service-vendor element, and a service-version element.
The service element contains a root-sbb element.
The root-sbb element contains an optional description element.
The root-sbb element contains an sbb-name element, an sbb-vendor element and an sbb-version element.
The service element contains a default-priority element.
The service element contains an optional address-profile-table element.
This Profile Table contains provisioned addresses that may cause new root SBB entities of the Service to be instantiated. This element specifies the Address Profile Table of the Service.
The Profile Specification of this Profile Table must be the same as the Profile Specification specified by the address-profile-spec-alias-ref of the root SBB.
The service element contains a resource-info-profile-table element.
The Profile Specification of this Profile Table must be the SLEE specification defined Resource Info Profile Specification.
The ServiceID interface (see Section 13.7.5.2) defines the interface of a Java object that encapsulates a Service's component identity.
The Service Deployer can modify the attribute-alias-name  element.
The Service Deployer can modify the env-entry elements.
The Service Deployer can modify the resource-adaptor-type-binding elements.
The Service Deployer can modify the resource-adaptor-entity-binding elements.
The Service Deployer can modify the ejb-ref elements.
The Service Deployer should avoid modifying other SBB deployment descriptor elements.
The SBB Developer distributes one or more Service deployment descriptors in a Service XML deployment descriptor file.
This file contains a singleservice-xml element.
The service-xml element contains an optional description element.
The service-xml element contains one or more service elements.  (See Section 3.4.1)

Before event types, Profile Specifications, SBBs and Services can be deployed or installed into a SLEE, the Service Deployer must create a deployable unit that contains the components that are to be deployed.
This jar file contains a deployable unit deployment descriptor, the constituent jar files and Service XML files of the deployable unit.
The deployable unit deployment descriptor is stored with the name META-INF/deployable-unit.xml in the deployable unit jar file.
The deployable unit deployment descriptor contains a deployment-unit element.
The deployable-unit element contains an optional description element.
The deployable-unit element contains one or more jar elements.
Each jar element contains the name of a constituent jar file included in the deployable unit jar file.
This name is relative to the root of the deployable unit jar file.
The deployable-unit element contains zero or more service-xml deployment descriptor elements.
This name is relative to the root of the deployable unit jar file.
An address is a unique identifier in a network or the SLEE.
An Address object is immutable.  Once it has been created, its contents cannot be changed.
An Address object must at least have both a valid address plan and a valid address string.  The address string must be of the format defined by the address plan.
The fromInt method (of an AddressPlan object) throws a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException if the plan argument is not one of the integer address plan representations.
The addressString String cannot contain wildcards.
The fromInt method (of an AddressPresentation object) throws a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException if the presentation argument is not one of the integer address presentation representations.
The fromInt method (of an AddressScreening object) throws a java.lang.IllegalArgumentException if the screening argument is not one of the integer address presentation representations.
The arguments of the methods of the SBB local interface are passed by reference.

An SBB that defines an SBB local interface must be coded to assume that the caller and callee may potentially reference the same Java object that is passed directly or indirectly as an argument or result.
All SBB local interfaces extend the SBBLocalObject interface.
If an SBB does not define an SBB specific local interface, then the SBB's local interface is SBBLocalObject.

This allows the SBB object to terminate processing gracefully.
All the above methods have at-most-once invocation semantics.  If an invocation of one of these methods fails, the SLEE must not re-invoke the method.

column8: The SLEE uses introspection of the SBB abstract class and the definitions in the SBB deployment descriptor to determine and generate the appropriate logic to interface the SBB to the SLEE.
An SBB object can be in one of three states: Does Not Exist, Pooled and Ready.
An SBB object's life cycle starts when the SLEE creates the object using newInstance.  The SLEE then invokes the setSbbContext method to pass the SBB object an SbbContext object.
column14: Set a flag when setSbbContext() is called. In an event handler, check that the flag was set.

column8: The SLEE invokes the sbbActivate method on an SBB object when an SBB object needs to be activated to receive a method invocation on an existing SBB entity.  This occurs when there is no existing SBB object in the Ready state assigned to the SBB entity.
column10: The SLEE is not required to keep a pool of Sbb objects. If no pool is kept, i.e. Sbb are never passivated, then no Sbb objects will ever need to be activated.

column8: While the SBB object is in the Ready state, the SLEE can sychronise the transient state held in the SBB object with the persistent state of the SBB entity whenever it determines the need to, by invoking the sbbLoad and sbbStore methods zero or more times.
The SLEE can choose to passivate an SBB object.

To passivate an SBB object, the SLEE first invokes the sbbStore method to allow the SBB object to prepare itself for the synchronisation of the SBB entity's persistent state with the SBB object's transient state, and then the SLEE invokes the sbbPassivate method to return the SBB object to the Pooled state.
column10: The SLEE is not required to keep a pool of Sbb objects, and there is no standard means to force passivation of Sbb objects.

column8: Eventually, the SLEE will transition the SBB object to the Pooled state.

There are three possible normal transitions from the Ready state to the Pooled state: through the sbbPassivate method, through the sbbRemove method, and because of a transaction rollback for sbbCreate or sbbPostCreate.
The SLEE invokes the sbbPassivate method when the SLEE wants to disassociate the SBB object from the SBB entity without removing the SBB entity.
The SLEE invokes the sbbRemove method when the SLEE wants to remove the SBB entity (i.e. when the SBB entity is removed as part of a cascading removal of an SBB entity sub-tree).

If sbbCreate and sbbPostCreate are called and successfully return without throwing a RuntimeException or CreateException, and subsequently the enclosing transaction rolls back, the SLEE will transition the SBB object to the Pooled state by invoking the sbbPassivate method.
column10: There is no requirement that sbbPassivate will be called at any particular time (other than before the instance is used again). As the SLEE may choose to delay this call forever, it is not testable.

The CMP field accessor methods must be declared but must not be implemented in the SBB abstract class.
The SLEE provides the implementation of the CMP fields.

The CMP fields must be specified in the SBB's deployment descriptor using the cmp-field elements respectively.  The names of these fields must be valid Java identifiers and must begin with a lowercase letter, as determined by java.lang.Character.isLowerCase.
The SBB Developer must declare the accessor methods fro the CMP fields as get and set methods, using the JavaBeans conventions.
The SLEE provides the implementation of the accessor methods.

The accessor methods must be public, must be abstract, and must bear the name of the CMP field that is specified in the cmp-field deployment descriptor element, and in which the first letter of the name of the CMP field has been uppercased and prefixed by "get" or "set".
The Java types of the CMP fields are restricted to Java primitive types, Java serializable types, and SBB local interfaces.
Since the SLEE specification does not require the SBB local interface or its derived types to be serializable, non-primitive CMP field types cannot contain SBB local interface types.
The SLEE maintains referential integrity for SBB entity references stored in CMP fields.
If the target SBB entity of a reference is deleted, the SLEE must in future return null from any CMP field accessor for a CMP field that referenced the target SBB entity.
column14: Store a reference to a child sbb in a CMP field.  Delete the child SBB.  Call getCMP() and verify that null was returned.

column8: Whether the sbb-alias-ref element of the cmp-field deployment descriptor is present determines whether the CMP field can hold a reference to an SBB entity. If the sbb-alias-ref element is not present, the CMP field cannot hold a reference to an SBB entity.
If the Java type of the CMP field is an SBB local interface (i.e., SbbLocalObject, or a type derived from SbbLocalObject), then the sbb-alias-ref element must be present.

column8: If the child not attached callback method is specified, the SLEE invokes this method when the attachment count of a child SBB entity decrements to zero (see Section 2.2.13).
The method must be public and must not be abstract or static.
The return type of the method must be void.
The name of the method must be a valid Java identifier.
The method must not throw any checked exceptions.
The method must not be exposed through the SBB local interface of the SBB.
The method is a mandatory transactional method (see Section 9.6.1).
The SLEE invokes this method within a transaction some time after the original transaction that decemented the attachment count of the child SBB to zero has committed.
This method can only be specified if the SBB has at least one child SBB declared in its deployment descriptor.

The SLEE invokes this callback method when the Administrator deactivates a Service (see Section 2.2.18 and Section 13.8).  The SLEE invokes this method on each SBB entity that is a member of an SBB entity tree instantiated by the SLEE for the Service.
The callback invocation is post-order.  The child SBB entities get their sbbServiceDeactivated callbacks before the parent SBB entity.
Among sibling SBB entities , a higher priority sibling SBB entity gets the callback before a lower priority SBB entity.
Callback order among sibling SBB entities with the same priority is not specified.
This method must be public and must not be abstract or static.

The SLEE invokes the sbbExceptionThrown callback method to handle RuntimeExceptions thrown by the event handler methods, the transaction rolled back callback method and the logical cascade removal method of the SBB abstract class.

column8: A well written SBB should not throw any RuntimeExceptions from any of its SLEE invoked methods. Instead the SBB should place the exception handling logic in a try {} catch () {} clause and handle RuntimeExceptions within each invoked method.

When a SLEE originated mandatory transaction method is invoked on an SBB object and the invocation returns with a RuntimeException thrown the SLEE marks the transaction of the invocation for rollback, logs the condition, then invokes the sbbExceptionThrown method of the same SBB object with the same transaction, moves the SBB object to the Does Not Exist state, ...

column8: The SBB object may be in the Pooled or the Ready state. If an event handler method throws a RuntimeException, then the SBB object remains in the Ready state when the SLEE invokes the sbbExceptionThrown method on the SBB object.

column8: When the SLEE invokes a non-transactional method of an SBB object and the invocation returns by throwing a RuntimeException, the SLEE performs the following sequence of operations: (1) it moves the SBB object to the Does Not Exist state (2) it must log this occurence.
column10: The non-transactional methods invoked on an Sbb object are setSbbContext, unsetSbbContext, sbbActivate and sbbPassivate.  We cannot force calls to sbbActivate and sbbPassivate (see 368,371). We cannot test for setSbbContext(), as throwing a RuntimeException from this method will prevent the Sbb object from leaving the Does Not Exist state anyway. We cannot test for unsetSbbContext(), as this call indicates that the Sbb object is already being moved to the Does Not Exist state.

column8: When the SLEE rolls back a txn, the SLEE may start zero or more new txns to deliver txn rolled back callbacks.

If the rolled back txn does not invoke any SBB entities, i.e. None of the SLEE originated invocations of the txn have a target SBB entity, then the SLEE does not start any new txns to deliver txn rolled back callbacks.

If the rolled back txn includes one or more SLEE originated invocations, then the SLEE starts a new transaction to deliver a txn rolled back callback for each of the SLEE originated invocations in the txn that has a target SBB entity.
column14: Cause an event handler TXN to rollback.  Verify that the TXN the sbbRolledBack callback is executed in is different to that used for the event handler.

column8: The SLEE may or may not be successful in delivering a transaction rolled back callback.  For example, if the SLEE does not already have an SBB object in the Ready state that represents the target SBB entity, then the SLEE has to invoke the necessary lifecycle  methods on an SBB object before it can invoke the sbbRolledBack method.  The SLEE does not invoke the sbbRolledBack method if one of these life cycle methods throws a RuntimeException and cause the txn  to be rolled back before the SLEE has an opportunity to invoke the sbbRolledBack method.

column8: The SLEE provides an implementation of the JNDI naming context that stores the SBB component environment.
The SLEE provides an entry for an SBB component identifier that identifies the SBB component.
The SLEE provides an entry for each SLEE Facility.
The SLEE provides an entry for each SLEE specification defined Activity Context Interface  Factory.

SBB Objects locate the environment naming context using the JNDI interfaces. An SBB Object creates a javax.naming.InitialContext object by using the constructor with no arguments, and looks up the environment naming via the InitialContext under the name java:comp/env.
SBB component identifier: slee/sbb/id
column14: Lookup sbb id from jndi.  Check returned object is assignable to the required interface.

column8: SLEE Facilities: slee/facilities/...
Resources: slee/resources/...
column10: Tested implicitly by all tests which use Sbbs, as all TCK Sbbs reference the TCK resource adaptor.

column8: The SBB Developer must declare all the environment entries accessed from the SBB component's code.  The environment entries are declared using the env-entry elements in the SBB deployment descriptor.
Each env-entry element d escribes a single environment entry.
Each env-element contains an optional description element.
Each env-element contains an env-entry-name element that specifies a  name relative to the java:comp/env context.
Each env-element contains an env-entry-type element that specifies the expected Java type of the environment entry value.
Each env-entry element contains an optional env-entry-value element that specifies the value of the environment entry.

An environment entry is scoped to the SBB component whose declaration contains the env-entry element.  This means that the environment entry is inaccessible from other SBB components at runtime, and that other SBB components may define env-entry elements with the same env-entry-name without causing a name conflict.
column14: Define environment entries with the same name but different values in different sbb types in parent/child relationships.  Also define an sbb type that doesn't have the environment entry defined.  Check values are correct in sbbs, or alternatively that the entry is not defined, as appropriate

column8: The environment entry values may be one of the following Java types: String, Character, Integer, Boolean, Double, Byte, Short, Long and Float.
column14: Define environment entries of all allowable types; check in sbb that all env entries appear in jndi with the right type

column8: If the SBB Developer provides a value for an environment entry using the env-entry-value element, the value can be changed later by the SBB Developer or Service Deployer.
The value must be a  string that is valid for the constructor of the specified type that takes a single String parameter, or for java.lang.Character, a single character.
The Service Deployer must ensure that the values of all the environment entries declared by the SBB component are set to meaningful values.

The Service Deployer can modify the values of the environment entries that have been previously set by the SBB Developer, and must set the values of those environment entries for which no value has been specified.
The SBB Developer must use resource adaptor type bindings to obtain references to resource adaptor type defined Activity Context Interface Factory objects (see Section 7.6.1) as follows.
Assign an entry in the SBB's component environment to the resource adaptor type binding.
Lookup the resource adaptor type defined Activity Context Interface Factory objects in the SBB's component environment using the JNDI interface.

Although a resource adaptor type binding is an entry in the SBB's component environment, the SBB Developer must not use an env-entry element to declare it.  Instead, the SBB Developer must declare all the resource adaptor type bindings in the SBB deployment descriptor using resource-adaptor-type-binding.
The resource-adaptor-type-binding contains an optional description element.

The resource-adaptor-type-binding contains a resource-adaptor-type-ref element, which identifies the resource adaptor type of the resource adaptor type binding.  It contains a resource-adaptor-type-name sub-element, a resource-adaptor-type-vendor sub-element, and a resource-adaptor-type-version sub-element.
The above sub-elements must match exactly the corresponding sub-elements in the resource-adaptor-type element (see Section 14.1.2) of the resource adaptor type.

The resource-adaptor-type-binding contains an activity-context-interface-factory-name element, which contains the name of the environment entry used in the SBB's component code to access an Activity Context Interface Factory object of the resource adaptor type.
The name of the environment entry is relative to the java:comp/env context (e.g. the name should be slee/resources/jcc/... rather than java:comp/env/slee/resources/jcc/...)
column10: Tested implicitly by all tests which use Sbbs, as all TCK Sbbs reference the TCK resource adaptor.

column8: The resource-adaptor-type-binding contains zero or more resource-adaptor-entity-binding elements (see Section 6.15.3.1.2).
Each SBB component has its own set of resource adaptor type binding entries.  The resource adaptor type binding environment entries are not shared with other SBB components.
The SBB component environment may not be modified at runtime.

The Service Deployer must ensure that the resource-adaptor-type-ref elements of all the resource-adaptor-type-binding elements declared by the SBB component are set to meaningful values.  Otherwise, the SBB cannot be installed in the SLEE.  The Service Deployer must set the values of those resource-adaptor-type-ref elements for which no value has been specified.

The SBB Developer must use resource adaptor entity bindings to obtain references to resource adaptor objects as follows: Assign an entry in the SBB's component environment to the resource adaptor entity binding.  Lookup the resource adaptor objects in the SBB's component environment using the JNDI interface.

Although a resource adapter entity binding is an entry in the SBB's component environment, the SBB Developer must not use an env-entry element to declare it.  Instead, the SBB Developer must declare all the resource adaptor entity bindings in the SBB deployment descriptor using resource-adaptor-entity-binding.
Each resource-adaptor-entity-binding element describes a single resource adaptor entity binding and is enclosed within a resource-adaptor-entity-binding element.
The resource-adaptor-entity-binding contains an optional description el ement.

The resource-adaptor-entity-binding contains a resource-adaptor-object-name element which contains the name of the environment entry used in the SBB component's code to access the target resource adaptor object of the resource adaptor entity binding.
The name of the environment entry is relative to the java:comp/env context.
column10: Tested implicitly by all tests which use Sbbs, as all TCK Sbbs reference the TCK resource adaptor.

column8: The resource-adaptor-entity-binding contains a resource-adaptor-entity-linx element which identifies the resource adaptor entity that will provide the resource adaptor object that should be bound into the JNDI component environment of the SBB.

The identified resource adaptor entity must be an instance of a resource adaptor whose resource adaptor type is specified by the resource-adaptor-type-ref sub-element of the enclosing resource-adaptor-type-binding element.
Each SBB  component has its own set of resource adaptor entity binding entries.
All instances of classes of an SBB component share the same resource adaptor entity binding environment entries; ...

column8: ... the resource adaptor entity binding environment entries are not shared with other components.

column8: The Service Deployer must ensure that the resource-adaptor-entity-link elements of all the resource-adaptor-entity-binding elements declared by the SBB component are set to meaningful values.
A resource-adaptor-entity-link must refer to a resource adaptor entity that is already instantiated in the SLEE.  Otherwise, the SBB cannot be installed in the SLEE.
The Service Deployer must set the values of those resource-adaptor-entity-link elements for which no value has been specified.
The SLEE has the responsibility of implementing the java:comp/env environment naming context, and providing it to SBB Objects at runtime.

Activity Contexts and Activity Context Interface objects: 1-to-many
Activity Contexts and SBBs: many-to-many

column8: An SBB entity can be attached to a particular Activity Context zero or one times.
An SBB entity will only receive events fired on Activity Contexts that it has been attached to.
The SLEE automatically attaches an SBB entity to an Activity Context when the SBB entity receives an initial event delivered on the Activity Context (see Section 8.5).

column8: An SBB entity may explicitly attach itself to an Activity Context.
column14: Create an Activity, get a hold of its ActivityContextInterface, then attach the SBB to that Activity.

column8: The SLEE automatically detaches an SBB entity from an Activity Context after the SLEE delivers an Activity End Event to the SBB entity.
column14: Create an SBB that's attached to an Activity.  Call Activity.endActivity() and make sure that the SBB is not attached to that activity any more by firing an event on another Activity it's attached to, then calling SbbContext.getActivities().

column14: Create a Parent SBB, create a Child SBB.  Attach the child SBB to a number of activity contexts.  Remove the child SBB.  Send an event on one of the Activities, which if the child is still attached will cause it to call a method on the parent, setting a variable to some non-default value.  Send an event on another activity, which causes the parent to check the value of this variable.

column8: An SBB entity may be explicitly detached from an Activity Context.
Each SLEE Facility can reference zero or more Activity Contexts.
Examples of SLEE Facilities that maintain references to Activity Contexts include the Timer Facility and the Activity Context Naming Facility.
Each Activity Context can be referenced by zero or more SLEE Facilities.
An Activity object has a Java type of java.lang.Object in the SLEE API.
The SLEE specification does not define a more specific Java type for every Activity object.
The SLEE and resource adaptors can define more specific types for Activity objects.
These types are always Objects.
The SLEE and Resource Adaptor entities can create new Activities.
The SLEE becomes aware of an Activity object in the following ways:
When an event is fired for the first time on the Activity object.
column10: The SLEE is made aware of the event and the activity via the resource adaptor. The resource adaptor API is not defined in this specification.

column8: When an Activity Context Interface object for interacting with the Activity Context of the Activity object is explicitly requested (see Section 7.6.1).
When the NullActivityFactory is asked to create a new Activity.
A NullActivity object represents an Activity that has no external source of events
The SLEE fires Service lifecycle Events on ServiceActivity objects (see Section 8.7)
The SLEE fires Profile Table and Profile lifecycle events on ProfileTableActivity objects
The SLEE fires Profile Updated Events on ProfileActivity objects (see Section 10.4).
The source of an Activity object is also the owner of the Activity object since it controls the lifetime of the Activity object.
The SLEE specification does not define any application visible API for firing an event on an Activity object.
The SLEE does not define any fire event method that takes an Activity object as an argument.
The SLEE specification defines an API that SBBs use to fire events on an Activity Context
Every Activity object must have an end.

When an Activity object ends, the SLEE delivers an Activity End Event to all SBB entities that are attached to the Activity Context of the Activity object and can receive the Activity End Event (see Section 8.5.5).
column14: Create an SBB, attach it to an Activity.  End that Activity object, make sure the SBB receives the Activity End Event.

column8: Any state stored in an Activity Context by an SBB entity is persistent for the lifetime of the Activity Context. An SBB entity detaching from an Activity Context can expect any information it has stored in the Activity Context to be persisted for later use by the same or another SBB entity.
column14: Declare a child SBB with a custom SbbActivityContextInterface.  Create instance of child, fire event, set value.  Remove instance of child.  Create another instance of child, fire event, get value.

column8: Activity Contexts are created and owned by the SLEE.
The SLEE creates a new Activity Context when it is presented with a new Activity object.
An Activity Context can be in one of three states: Active, Ending and Invalid.
If an SBB entity attempts to fire an event on an Activity Context in the Ending state, the SLEE will throw a javax.lang.IllegalStateException.
column14: Create an Activity, end it, then in the ActivityEndEvent handler try to fire an event on its ACI.  Should receive IllegalStateException.

column8: While in this state (Ending), the SLEE will continue to deliver outstanding events fired on the Activity Context.
column14: Create a parent and child SBB that both receive the same event.  Fire that event.  The parent's event handler will be called first (spec mandated), in that handler call endActivity() on the activity.  The child should also receive the event as it is outstanding.  Further events sent after the endActivity() should not be received. 12 Nov 2004: The wasn't doing the above, and was removed as an invaliad test on 12 Nov 04 (see the TCK bug list for details). No replacement test was written, as this assertion is covered by Test562.

column8: After the outstanding events have been delivered, the SLEE will fire an Activity End Event on the Activity Context.
column14: Create an SBB, fire an event, in the event handler create an activity, fire an event on the activity, then end the activity.  Ensure that the event fired is delivered before the ActivityEnd event is received.

column8: The SLEE delivers the Activity End Event to each interested SBB entity attached  to the Activity Context and detaches each interested SBB entity from the Activity Context.  The SLEE also detaches the SBB entities attached to the AC that are not interested in the Activity End Event.

The Activity Context transitions to the Invalid state from the Ending state when no SBB entity is attached to the Activity Context (see Section 7.1.3) and no SLEE Facility references the Activity Context (see Section 7.1.4).

The SBB Activity Context Interface interface must be public.
The SBB Developer must declare a set accessor method and/or a get accessor method for each shareable attribute in the SBB Activity Context Interface interface.
The rules for computing accessor method names from an attribute name are the same as the rules for computing accessor method names from a CMP field name (see Section 6.5.1).
The Java types of an Activity Context attribute are restricted to Java primitive types and Java serializable types.  SBB local interfaces cannot be stored in Activity Context attributes.
The semantics of these accessor methods are also the same as the semantics of CMP field accessor methods.

The SBB abstract class of an SBB that defines an SBB Activity Context Interface interface must declare an asSbbActivityContextInterface method.
This method takes as its input parameter an Activity Context Interface object and returns an object that implements the SBB Activity Context Interface interface of the SBB.
The SBB Activity Context Interface interface provides the accessor methods that allow an SBB object to access the shareable attributes of the SBB that are stored in the Activity Context.
If the SBB does not define an SBB Activity Context Interface interface, then this method cannot be declared in the SBB abstract class.
The method signature of this method is as follows:  public abstract <SBB Activity Context Interface> asSbbActivityContextInterface(ActivityContextInterface activity);
The method must be declared as public and abstract.
The SLEE provides the concrete implementation of the method when the SBB is deployed.
The return type must be the Activity Context Interface interface of the SBB, or a base interface of the Activity Context Inteface interface of the SBB.
This method (asSbbActivityContextInterface) does not have a throws clause.
The SBB object must have an assigned SBB entity when it invokes this method. Otherwise, this method throws a java.lang.IllegalStateException.

column8: For communiction among SBB entities, the SBB entities should use events to signal each other and use Activity Contexts to share common state.  This reduces the use direct references among SBB entities and references to SBB entities by other entities.
Event producers fire events.  Event consumers receive events.  The SLEE event router delivers events fired by event producers to event consumers.
The only event consumers defined by the SLEE are SBB entities.  The SLEE specification defines how events are delivered to SBB entities.
Although resource adaptor entities  may also receive events, the SLEE specification does not define how this is done.
Each SBB that fires events must declare the event types that it fires.  For each event type that the SBB fires, the SBB Developer declares an abstract fire event method in the SBB abstract class.
The abstract fire event method is implemented by the SLEE when the SBB is installed into the SLEE as part of a deployment unit.
column14: Fire an event and verify that it is received.

column8: Each SBB that receives events must declare the event types that it receives.  For each event type that the SBB receives, the SBB defines and implements an event handler method in its SBB abstract class.
This event handler method contains application logic to process events of the event type.

The SLEE event router invokes an event handler method of an SBB object to hand an event to the SBB object for processing. The event name binding for the event type that the event handler method receives determines the name of the event handler method (see Section 8.4.2).
column14: SBB TestSBB defines two event handlers for event class TCKResourceEventX, for types X1 and X2. The resource fire an X1 event followed by an X2 event. Check that the SBB  receives each event via the event handler.

column8: An event object is the Java object that represents the event and carries the information to by conveyed.
An event object must be a java.lang.Object, i.e. it cannot be a primitive type.

When an event producer fires an event, it must provide to the SLEE the event type of the event.  The event type of the event completely determines how the SLEE will route the event, i.e. which SBB entities will receive the event, and which event handler method will be invoked to process the event.

The human  readable representation of an event type is composed of three strings containing the event type's name, vendor and version.  Hence, an event type identifier consists of the event type's name, vendor and version.  This representation of the event type is used in deployment descriptor elements.
All custom events must be serializable.
All custom events must implement hashCode.
The new hashCode method does not need to provide hash codes that are unique but does need to provide hash codes that are well distributed.
All custom events must implement equals.
The new equals method must ensure that the implementation of the method is reflexive, symmetric, transitive and for any non-null value X X.equals(null) returns false.
An event name must conform to the naming requirements of Java method names.
When an event producer fires an event, it must provide to the SLEE, either directly or indirectly, the event.  This includes the Java event object and the event type.
When an event producer fires an event, it must provide to the SLEE, either directly or indirectly, the Activity Context the event is f ired on.
When an event producer fires an event, it must provide to the SLEE, either directly or indirectly, an optional default address.

If the event type of the event is an initial event type of a Service and the initial event policy for the event type is a built-in policy that uses the default address, the SLEE event router uses the default address together with the Address Profile Table of the Service (see Section 10.14.2) to determine whether a new root SBB entity of the Service should be instantiated to process the event.  If a new root SBB entity is instantiated, this event is the new SBB entity's initial event (see Section 8.5.1).
When the SLEE delivers an event to an SBB entity, it invokes the event handler method for the event's event type on an SBB object that is assigned to the SBB entity.

The SLEE passes the event object (or a copy of the event object) handed to it by the event producer to the event handler method.  The event type of the event determines which of the event handler methods of the SBB abstract class is invoked by the SLEE to process the event.
column14: Create an SBB, which has FireAndReceive for a custom event type.  Create the Event object to be fired, store it in a CMP field, then fire the event.  In the receive event handler compare the event with that stored in the CMP field using equals()  (not direct comparison as a copy is ok).

column8: The SLEE passes to the event handler method an object implementing the SBB Activity Context Interface interface.  The SBB entity uses this object to interact with the Activity Context on which the event was fired and the underlying Activity object of the Activity Context (see Section 7.1.1).
column14: SBB defines an ACI type and does an instanceof comparison with the ACI in its event handler

column8: The SLEE specification defines two sets of event-related deployment descriptor elements: deployment descriptor elements specified by event producers that declare the event types and event classes that the event producers fire, and, deployment descriptor elements specified by SBB Developers that declare how SBBs use different event types.
Every event producer must identify the event types that it fires.
An SBB declares each event type it fires in an event deployment descriptor element in its sbb deployment descriptor element.
A resource adaptor type declares each event type its resource adaptor entities fire in an event deployment descriptor element in its resource-adaptor-type deployment descriptor element.
Other event producers declare the event types they fire in other deployment descriptors.
Each event-definition element contains an optional description element.

Each event-definition element contains an event-type element, an event-type-vendor element, and an event-type-version element.  Together these elements contain the human readable representation of the event type.

Each event-definition element contains an event-class-name element.  This element provides the Java type for the event parameter of the event handler method that receives events of the specified event type or the fire event method that fires events of the specified event type.

Each event element contains an initial-event attribute.  This attribute indicates if the event type is an initial event (see Section 8.5.1).  This attribute is meaningful only if the SBB is received the specified event type.
Each event element contains an event-direction attribute.
The value of the event-direction attribute can be "Receive", "Fire" or "FireAndReceive".
column14: Define an Sbb with all 3 valid event-directions, and another Sbb with an invalid event-direction. Check that the valid Sbb installs, and that the invalid Sbb doesn't.

column8: Each event element contains a mask-on-attach attribute.
The mask-on-attach attribute is only meaningful if the event direction is "Receive" or "FireAndReceive".
By default the event type is not masked.
column14: Create an SBB which has two events of Receive, with initial-event=True, one of which has mask-on-attach explicitly set to False, the other doesn't specify this attribute.  Fire the unspecified masked event first, then the other event.  In the unspecified masked handler set a CMP field variable, in the other handler check for this variable and return a test result.

column8: Each event element contains an optional description element.

Each event element contains an event-type-ref element.  This element contains the following an event-type-name element, an event-type-vendor element and an event-type-version element.  These elements uniquely identify an event type declared in an event-definition element specified in another deployment descriptor.  An event-definition element declares an event type (see Section 8.3.1).
Each event element contains an event-name element.
Each event element contains zero or more initial-event-select elements.
Each initial-event-select element contains a variable attribute.
The value of the variable attribute can be one of "ActivityContext", "AddressProfile", "Address", "EventType" or "Event".
Each event element contains an event-resource-option element.
The SLEE does not interpret the content in this element.  The event producer of the identified event type interprets this content.
Each element contains an optional initial-event-selector-method-name element.  This element is only meaningful if initial-event is true.
The SLEE invokes this optional method to determine if an event of the specified event type is an initial event if the SBB is a root SBB of a Service (see Section 8.5.4).
column10: Covered by the convergence name tests which use the initial event selector method (the given list is a subset of these)

column8: If different SBBs specify conflicting options, the event producer is responsible for resolving the conflict.
For each event type fired by an SBB, the SBB Developer must provide an event element in the SBB's deployment descriptor element.
The value of the event-direction attribute of the event element must be "Fire" or "FireAndReceive".  The event element must also include an event-name element and an event-type-ref element.
For each event type fired by an SBB, the SBB Developer must provide an event-definition element if the SBB introduces a new custom event type.

If the custom event type that will be fired by the SBB does not already have an event-definition deployment descriptor element, the SBB Developer must provide an event-definition element for the newly introduced custom event type.
For each event type fired by an SBB, the SBB Developer must declare an abstract fire event method in the SBB abstract class.
The SLEE implements this abstract method when the SBB in installed into the SLEE.
The fire event method must be declared as public and abstract.
The fire event method does not have a throws clause.
The event and activity arguments cannot be null.  If either argument is null, the fire event method throws a java.lang.NullPointerException.
The address argument provides the optional default address.
If there is no default address, then it should be null.

In the case of an SBB object as an event producer, the SBB object provides an Activity Context Interface object to identify the Activity Context, and an Address object ot provide the default address.  The address argument must be null if there is no default address.  See Section 8.5.
The SBB object must have an assigned SBB entity when it invokes this method. Otherwise, this method throws a java.lang.IllegalStateException.
column14: A child SBB attempts to invoke a fire event method from its sbbCreate call, it gets the AC from the naming facility. It tries to catch the exception. If exception thrown pass, otherwise fail.

column8: It is a mandatory transactional method.  Hence, the SBB object must invoke this method within a transaction.  It throws a javax.slee.TransactionRequiredLocalException if it is invoked without a valid transaction context.
column10: We never have a guaranteed 'non-transactional' context to test from.

column8: It throws a javax.slee.SLEEException if the requested operation cannot be performed due to a system-level failure.
An SBB object cannot modify an event object after it passes the event object as an argument to a fire event method invocation.
An SBB object cannot modify the event object even after the fire event method returns.
An SBB object can only invoke its own fire event methods.
An SBB object can only invoke fire event methods from within an execution thread used to deliver an event to the SBB object.
The execution behaviour of the SBB object and the SLEE is undefined if these restrictions are not followed.
For each event type received by an SBB, the SBB Developer must provide an event element in the SBB's deployment descriptor element.
The value of the event-direction attribute must be "Receive" or "FireAndReceive".
It must also include an event-name element and an event-type-ref element.
The event element may optionally include an event-resource-option element.
For each event type received by an SBB, the SBB Developer must implement an event handler in the SBB abstract class.

The name of the event handler method is derived from the event name of the event type that will be received by the event handler method.  The method name of the event handler method is derived by adding an "on" prefix to the event name.
The event handler method must be declared as public and cannot be static, abstract, or final.
The event handler method is a mandatory transactional method (see Section 9.6.1.1).  Hence the SLEE always invoke this method within a transaction.
An SBB Activity Context Interface object represents the Activity Context on which the event was fired.
The event handler method may return by throwing an unchecked exception.  See section 6.11 and Section 6.12.1 on how the SLEE handles this situation.
Event handler methods cannot modify event objects passed t o it.
After an event handler method invocation returns, the invoked SBB object cannot continue to hold a reference to the event object passed to the event handler method, either directly or indirectly.
The execution behaviour of the SBB object and the SLEE is undefined if these restrictions are not followed.
The eventNames argument specifies the event names of the event types that should be masked.

column8: A null or empty argument unmasks all previously masked event types.
