column8: It throws a javax.slee.SLEEException if the requested operation cannot be performed due to a system-level failure.
A SLEE implementation may filter out masked events immediately before event delivery.
As an optimization, a SLEE implementation may also modify underlying resource event filters to drop events of masked event types.
A potential root SBB must have at least one event attribute with the initial-event attribute set to "True".

When an event producer fires an event on an Activity Context, the following algorithm is used to determine whether the event is an initial event for each active Service.  Determine the set of active Services whose set of initial event types includes the event type of the event....

When the SBB entity is being attached to the Activity Context, the SLEE event router sets the event mask of the Activity Context with respect to the SBB entity according to the mask-on-attach attributes of the event deployment descriptor elements of the SBB.

Once the new or existing SBB entity is attached to the Activity Context, the root SBB entity will receive the event when the SLEE event router delivers the event to the SBB entities attached to the Activity Context.

column8: Activity Context identifier:  The value of this variable (if selected) is the identifier that uniquely identifies an Activity Context within the SLEE.  This value is SLEE implementation specific and is known only to the SLEE.
There are no SBB visible APIs to obtain or interact with Activity Context identifiers.

This value of this variable (if selected) is the unique name of an Address Profile, in the Address Profile Table of the Service, that contains the default address returned by the initial event selector method or passed to the event router when the event was fired by the event producer if no initial event selector method was invoked for the Service.
If no such Address Profile exists in the Address Profile Table ... then the value of [the Address Profile] variable is null.

column8: A default address, or the address returned by an initial event selector method, can only be present in at most one Address Profile in an Address Profile Table. Hence, a single address maps to at most one Address Profile identifier and the SLEE constructs at most one convergence name for the identifier of the at most one Address Profile that the address is present in.
The default address and the selection of the Address Profile identifier in the convergence name play an important role in the creation of a convergence name.

If the Address Profile identifier is selected for inclusion in the convergence name and the default address is not null, but a matching Address Profile is not found, no convergence name is created for the SBB for the event and the event is not an initial event for the SBB.

column8: The initial event selector method may use the set accessor methods of the InitialEventSelector object to modify the InitialEventSelector object.

column8: The SLEE event router guarantees that there will be no concurrent execution within a single SBB object.  The SLEE will invoke all the methods of an SBB serially.  These methods include the event handler methods, the local interface methods, and the life cycle callback methods.
column10: The objective of the test is to try to get the SLEE to process events on different activities in parallel in the same sbb object. If this objective is met, the test fails. This test must allow for multiple VMs - which is why we allocate sbb object ID's in the test driver, rather than use System.identityHashCode().

column14: The Sbb declares 'Address' as the only convergence name variable; event types X1,Y1,Y2 and Y3 as initial events; and a private getSbbObjectID() method which provides synchronized access to the instance specific, create once variable 'sbbObjectID'. On 1st call, getSbbObjectID() gets the unique id from the test. Create activites A and B. Fire an X1 event on A. The test accepts ACKs from the Sbb, some of which block and fire a Y1,Y2 or Y3 event. The X1 event handler calls the blocking method, which fires a Y1 event on B. The X1 event handler then throws a RuntimeException. In sbbExceptionThrown, call the test, which will block and fire a Y2 event on B. In the sbbRolledBack call for X1, call the test, which will block and fire a Y3 event on B. In the Y1,Y2 and Y3 event handlers, send an ACK to the test with the sbbObjectID of the Sbb object. If sbbRolledBack() is called for Y1, Y2, or Y3, send an ACK to the test with the sbbObjectID of the Sbb object. If any ACK is received from an Sbb object which is currently also in inside another method, the test fails. The test passes when ACKs for the invocations of the X1 event handler, sbbExceptionThrown and sbbRolledBack methods are received, and at least one of an event handler ACK, an sbbRolledBack ACK or an eventProcessingSuccessful/Failed callback is received for each for each of the Y events (Y1,Y2,Y3).

column8: The SLEE event router guarantees that two or more SBB entities will not concurrently receive events on any single Activity Context.
column12: Multiple instances of: same Sbb component; different Sbb components.
column13: Multiple instances of: same Sbb component; different Sbb components.
column14: Define 2 Sbb components: Sbb1 and Sbb2. Both declare 'Address' as the only convergence name variable. Sbb1 declares X1,X2,and Y1 as initial event types, Sbb2 declares Y2 as an initial event type. Each event is fired on a new address, so a new Sbb instance is created for each event. Each event handler calls a synchronous ACK method on the test.  Test case 1 - same Sbb component:  Fire an X1 event on activity A. In the X1 ACK call, the test fires an X2 event on activity A, then blocks for some length of time.  If the test receives an ACK for X2 while blocking for X1, the test fails.  The test case finishes when the 2 ACKs (one from each Sbb instance), or an eventProcessingSuccessful/Failed callback is received for X2. Test case 2 - different Sbb components: Fire a Y1 event on activity B.  In the Y1 ACK call, the test fires a Y2 event on activity B, then blocks for some length of time.  If the test receives an ACK for Y2 while blocking for Y1, the test fails.  The test passes when the ACK, or an eventProcessingSuccessful/Failed callback is received for Y2.

column8: This allows the SBB Developer to develop event handler methods without having to consider the implications of multiple execution threads that may interact with the same Activity Context and the same underlying Activity object.
Since an event is always fired on an Activity Context, the SLEE event routert will always deliver the event serially to SBB entities that may receive the event.
The order in which these SBB entities receive the event depends on their event delivery priorities (see Section 8.5.7).
The default-priority element of the service deployment descriptor element of a Service specifies the event delivery priority of the root SBB entities instantiated by the SLEE for the Service.

column8: A parent SBB entity can modify the event delivery priority of a child SBB entity at runtime by invoking the setSbbPriority method on an SBB local object that represents the child SBB entity.
The event delivery priority of an SBB entity is an integer in the range of -128 through 127, inclusive.
column14: Valid event priorities are tested by just about every test that has a child SBB. To test the invalid case create a child SBB with an invalid default-priority, e.g. 204.

column8: -128 is the lowest priority.
column14: Create parent SBB with two children, one having -128 priority, the other having 127 priority.  Ensure that the one with 127 priority receives a fired event first.

column8: 127 is the highest priority.
100 to 127 for the highest event delivery priority.
31 to 99 for the high event delivery priority.
-30 to 30 for standard event delivery priority.
-99 to -31 for low event delivery priority.
-128 to -100 for lowest priority.
The SLEE delivers the event to a parent SBB entity before it delivers the event to the child SBB enities of the parent SBB entity.
column14: Create SBB and child.  Fire event that both can receive.  Ensure that parent receives it first.

column8: Among sibling SBB entities with the same parent, the SLEE delivers the event to a sibling SBB entity with a higher priority before it delivers the event to a sibling SBB entity with a lower priority.

If the sibling SBB entities have child SBB entities, the SLEE delivers the event to the child SBB entities of the higher priority sibling SBB entity after it delivers the event to the higher priority sibling SBB entity and before it delivers the event to the lower priority sibling SBB entity.  Hence, the event delivery order is higher priority sibling, children of higher priority sibling, lower priority sibling, then children of lower priority sibling.
column14: Create parent and two children.  Each of those children then has a single child.  Name P, C1, C2, CC1 and CC2.  Fire event that C1->CC2 receive, on reception send TCK test message containing integer value of expected place in event sequence (ie C1 = 0, CC1 = 2, C2 = 3, CC2 = 4), and verify that TCK receives the integers in ascending order.

column8: The order in which an event is delivered to sibling SBB entities with the same event delivery priority is not specified, i.e. the SLEE implementation determines the order.

When the SLEE delivers an event to an SBB entity, it checks the event mask associated with the SBB entity and the Activity Context.  If the event is masked, the SLEE does not invoke the event handler method for the event type of the event.

column8: Even though the SBB entity did not receive the event, the SLEE considers the event delivered to the SBB entity.

After the SLEE delivers the event to an SBB entity, it determines if one or more SBB entities that were not attached to the Activity Context prior to delivering the event to the SBB entity have become attached to the Activity Context.  If so, the SLEE must deliver the same event to these newly attached SBB entities.

column14: Create SBB, create child SBB.  Fire two events that both receive.  In parent handler increment CMP field counter, in child handler cause detach parent from ACI using parent SbbLocalObject provided via child local interface, then reattach parent.  In second handler verify that the CMP counter's value - if set to 2 pass, else fail.  If the child's second handler gets called the parent has not been reattached and the test errors. Note: the event delivery priority of child 1 must be higher than for child 2 (addressed by the fix for bug #5).

column8: An SBB entity that has received the event in the past but became detached and then reattached will receive this event again if it remains attached and the event is not masked.
The SLEE must implement automatic event subscription.
Automatic event subscription performs initial event subscription on behalf of active Services (see Section 8.6.1).
Automatic event subscription performs received event subscription on behalf of SBB enitities (see Section 8.6.2).

The SLEE is expected to collaborate with its resource adaptor entities to automatically install event triggers and filters into the underlying resources to subscribe and unsubscribe events.  These event filters allow the resource adaptor entities and underlying resources to install the appropriate event triggers and filters close to the event source and thus avoid transporting a large number of unwanted events to the SLEE.

The current SLEE specification does not define how SLEE vendors should implement automatic event subscription and the API used between the SLEE and resource adaptor entities to perform automatic event subscription.  A future specification is expected to define how the SLEE and its resource adaptor entities interact to perform automatic event subscription.

The SLEE provides a standard mechanism to help a Service set event filters to subscribe for the initial events of the potential root SBB entities of the Service (i.e. the initial events of the Service).
The root SBB of a Service specifies the initial event types of the Service.
The Address Profile Table of the Service specifies the subscribed address set of the Service.
The Service's subscribed address set is the set of addresses in the addresses attribute of all Address Profiles in the Address Profile Table of the Service.
The initial event set of a Service is the cross product of the initial event types of the Service and the Service's subscribed addresses set.
The SLEE's initial event set is the union of the initial event sets of all active Services, i.e. Services in the Active state, running in the SLEE.
The SLEE actively modifies the affected event triggers and filters when the SLEE's initial event set changes as a result of administrative actions.

In addition to the SLEE's initial event set, the SLEE must also ensure that SBB entities running in the SLEE receive events of their received event types (which also includes the initial event types).
The received event set of the SLEE is the set of events that all SBB entities running in the SLEE should receive.
The received event set of the SLEE changes when an operation that modifies the set of events that an SBB entity can receive is invoked.
The SLEE actively modifies affected event filters when the SLEE's received event set changes.
The SLEE fires a Service Started Event on a ServiceActivity object after the Service is started.

column8: Daemon-like Service entities with SBB entities that attach only to a ServiceActivity object can use the natural end of this Activity to help manage their own lifecycle.

Since SBB entities are detached from an Activity when the Activity ends, Service entities with SBB entities that are only attached to a ServiceActivity object will be detached when the Activity ends, causing their attachment count to decrement to zero thus allowing the SLEE to reclaim those Service entities.

All SLEEs must implement the transactional semantics defined in this specification.

Although a SLEE vendor may implement the specified transactional semantics using transactions as defined in the Java Transaction Architecture (JTA), not all SLEE vendors are required to use JTA as the underlying implementation technology.  The SLEE specification does not mandate JTA.
An example of transactional execution state is SBB CMP attributes.
The mechanism by which a compliant SLEE implementation provides atomicity guarantees is not defined by this specification.

All transactions are isolated from each other at the serializable isolation level. [...] This [...] means changes to the transactional execution state of one transaction are not visible to other concurrently executing transactions.

column8: Each transaction in the SLEE has an implicit state machine.
A transaction may be in one of the following states: Active, Committing, Committed, Marked for Rollback, Rolling Back, Rolled Back.
The SLEE handles all transitions between the various states of the transaction finite state machine.
An SBB object may directly cause a transition between the Active and Marked for Rollback states by invoking the setRollbackOnly method.
column14: Mark TXN for rollback in event handler, call getRollbackOnly() and verify that the SBB is marked for rollback.

column8: A transaction enters the Active state on initialization.
column10: Sbbs have no view of this txn state transition.

column8: When in the Active state, the transaction context is propagated to any invoked transactional methods (see Section 9.6 for a list of transactional methods).
column14: Fire an event on an SBB, verify that the TXN context in the event handler is non-null.

column8: On successful completion of a SLEE originated invocation sequence the transaction transitions from the Active state to the Committing state.
column10: Sbbs have no view of this txn state transition.

column8: If the commit succeeds the transaction either transitions to the end state or, if heuristics are present, transitions to the Committed state.  Otherwise, it enters the Rolled Back state.
column10: Sbbs have no view of this txn state transition, and there is no standard means to influence which path is taken.

column8: The SLEE specification does not define the semantics of transaction heuristics in the Committed state.  For more information on possible transaction heuristics refer to JTA.
The Marked for Rollback state is an extension of the transaction life cycle provided by the SLEE.
When a transaction is in this state the SLEE guarantees that any changes made to the transactional execution state will be rolled back.
column14: Set a txn for rollback, then set CMP fields and test that the CMP fields have been rolled back after the txn commits.

column8: A transaction may enter the Marked for Rollback state from the Active state.

column8: A transaction enters this state when the SBB invocation returns abnormally, i.e. it throws a RuntimeException.  In this case the SLEE marks the transaction for rollback.
A transaction enters this state when the SBB invocation directly or indirectly invokes the sbbSetRollback method.
A transaction enters this state when a transactional method of a SLEE Facility, resource, or EJB marks the transaction for rollback.

column8: The SLEE may roll back a transaction due to internal failures.  In these cases, the SLEE originated invocation sequence may have successfully completed execution, e.g. The methods in the SLEE originated invocation sequence returned without throwing a RuntimeException.
In the Rolled Back state the transaction has been aborted, i.e. the transaction execution state has been restored to its original value.

A transaction may enter the Rolled Back state from the Committing state.  The transaction enters this state from the Committing state when the SLEE is unable to successfully commit the transaction.

column8: Transactional methods defined by the SLEE specification are further divided into mandatory transactional methods and required transactional methods.

Mandatory transactional methods are methods that must be invoked from within a transaction.  If they are not invoked from within a transaction the SLEE must throw a javax.slee.TransactionRequiredLocalException.
column10: We can't test the non-transactional case, as we never have a guaranteed non-transactional context to invoke the method from. Regarding SLEE invoked, Sbb implemented methods, the requirement for a valid txn context is covered by other assertions.

column8: Required transactional methods are methods that may or may not be invoked from within a transaction.  If they are not invoked from within a transaction, a new transaction is created for the duration of the method invocation.
column10: We never have a guaranteed non-transactional context to invoke the method from.

column8: Both mandatory and required transaction methods execute in the same transaction context as the calling method.

column8: When a method of a transactional resource or EJB is invoked, this method may or may not be invoked with a transactional context corresponding to the transaction of the SLEE originated invocation.  Whether this context is propagated depends on the SLEE implementation and the EJB container implementation.  For further discussion see Section 9.8.
Mandatory transactional methods may only be invoked from within a transaction in the Active or Marked for Rollback state otherwise the SLEE must throw a javax.slee.TransactionRequiredLocalException.

column8: SBB local interface methods.

The methods of an SBB local interface execute in the calling methods transaction context. For example if an SBB entity invokes a method on an SBB local interface and the called SBB entity invokes its setRollbackOnly method, then after the invocation returns the callers getRollbackOnly returns true.

column8: The methods of a ChildRelation object execute in the caller's transaction context. Any transactional state changes caused by child SBB entity creation and removal are viewed as having taken effect within the calling transaction and only take effect if the calling transaction commits.
column14: ChildRelation.remove(), setRollbackOnly(), child doesn't exist at this point, but should exist when the transaction rolls back - to test fire three events on SBB.  In the first create the child, in the second remove the child, then setRollbackOnly(), in the third fire an event which the child should receive and mark test as success.  If the child doesn't receive the event the parent will mark the test as failure in its own event handler for the fired event.

In third event lookup the nullactivity, verify it's still there then fire two evetns on it.  In first handler lookup null activity, end it.  In second event retrieve null activity, try to fire third event on it, expect illegal stat exception (ended).  If third handler called send test failure.

Can't store in ACNF, as this will also rollback when the TXN rolls back.

Transactional methods of transactional resources (see Section 9.9).
The SLEE invokes the following mandatory transactional methods: SBB abstract class event handler methods.

If the SLEE invokes an event handler method of an SBB object to process an event that has been fired asynchronously, then the following rules govern how the SLEE may use the same transaction for other method invocations: the SLEE cannot invoke any other event handler method with the same transaction.

If the SLEE invokes an event handler method of an SBB object to process an event that has been fired asynchronously, then the following rules govern how the SLEE may use the same transaction for other method invocations: the SLEE can invoke zero or more mandatory transactional life cycle methods of the same SBB object with the same transaction.
column10: (It would not be possible to fail this assertion, as it's not possible to execute < 0 mandatory transactional life cycle methods in the same TXN)

column8: The SLEE may invoke these mandatory transactional life cycle methods before and/or after invoking the event handler method.

If the SLEE invokes an event handler method of an SBB object to process an event that has been fired asynchronously, then the following rules govern how the SLEE may use the same transaction for other method invocations: If any of the methods invoked with the same transaction returns by throwing an unchecked exception, then the SLEE invokes the sbb ExceptionThrown method of the same SBB object with the same transaction.  The SLEE also passes to the sbb ExceptionThrown method the same event object and Activity Context that were passed to the event handler method invoked in the same transaction.
The SLEE invokes the  following mandatory transactional methods: SBB abstract class child not attached callback method (see Section 6.9).  The SLEE always invokes this method with a new transaction.
The SLEE invokes the following mandatory transactional methods: SBB abstract class sbbRolledBack method (see Section 9.11).  The SLEE always invokes this method with a new transaction.
A SLEE originated invocation is one or more mandatory transactional method invocations performed by the SLEE with the same transaction on a single SBB object.
If an invoked method is a transactional method (mandatory or required), then the invoked method run in the same transaction as the top-level method invoked by the SLEE.

If an invoked method is a non-transactional method, then the invoked method does not run in the same transaction as the top-level method invoked by the SLEE.  The invoked method runs with an unspecified transaction context (see Section 9.7.1).

If a required transactional method is invoked from within a trasaction, the calling method's transaction context is propagated to the called method.

column8: A non-transactional method is a method that must not directly or indirectly read or modify transactional execution state.  Non-transactional methods include:
SBB abstract class setSbbContext, unsetSbbContext, sbbActivate and sbbPassivate life cycle methods.

A non-transactional method is always invoked in an unspecified transaction context.

column8: The term "an unspecified transaction context" is used in the SLEE specification to refer to the cases in which the SLEE specification does not fully define the transaction semantics of a method invocation.
The SLEE specification does not prescribe how a SLEE implementation should manage the execution of a method with an unspecified transaction context.

When the transactional semantics of an unspecified transaction context is unknown, a method that runs with an unspecified transaction context must be written conservatively and not rely on any particular transaction semantics.

A failure that occurs in the middle of the execution of a method that runs with an unspecified transaction context may leave any resource, transactional and non-transactional state accessed method from the method in an unpredictable state.  The SLEE specification does not define how the application should recover state after such a failure.
The SLEE may directly or indirectly invoke transactional methods:

Direct method invocation, also known as SLEE originated method invocation: The SLEE directly invokes a transactional method if there is no other SBB Developer implemented method invocation, such as an SBB abstract class method, and no other logical cascading removal method invocation (see below) in the call-chain leading to the current method invocation.

Direct method invocation, also known as SLEE originated method invocation: The SLEE directly invokes a transactional method if there is no other SBB Developer implemented method invocation, such as an SBB abstract class method, and no other logical cascading removal method invocation (see below) in the call-chain leading to the current method invocation.
Logical cascading removal methods are mandatory transactional methods.

When a logical cascading removal method is invoked, the method invocation may cause additional transactional methods to be invoked. These additional method invocations are always considered to be non-SLEE originated method invocations. The transactional methods that may be invoked include the life cycle methods of the SBB entities in the SBB entity tree or the SBB entity sub-tree being removed.

A SLEE originated logical cascading removal method invocation is initiated by the SLEE to reclaim an SBB entity tree after the attachment count of the root SBB entity of the SBB entity tree decreases to zero. When the method invocation completes, an entire SBB entity tree should be removed.
When the method invocation (logical cascading removal method) completes, an entire SBB entity tree should be removed.
column14: Parent with two children attached to the ACI.  Remove the child which has highest event priority.  Fire event that both children can receive, verify that only the second child receives the event.

column8: The SLEE specification does not specify whether or not the SLEE invokes the logical cascading removal method in the same transaction that decreases the attachment count of the root SBB to zero. Thus, a SLEE may implement eager and/or lazy reclamation of SBB entity trees.
If the cascading removal operation does not occur in the same transaction (i.e. eager reclamation), the SLEE must behave as if the SBB entity tree has become non-existent.
It must remove any convergence name associated with the root SBB entity of the SBB entity tree, i.e. the same convergence name may cause the SLEE to instantiate a new root SBB entity.
column10: We can't test lazy reclamation  explicitly as this is an implementation choice, but we can test expected reclamation behaviour  such that non-compliant implementations of lazy reclamation are detected.
column14: Install an SBB with 'activity' as the only convergence name variable selected. Fire an event on Activity Foo. In an event handler method, detach from Foo activity such that the SBB's attachment count is zero. Fire an initial event for the SBB on Foo, and check that a new SBB instance is created.

column8: It must also not deliver events to SBB entities in the  "non-existent"  SBB entity tree.
column10: We can't test lazy reclamation  explicitly as this is an implementation choice, but we can test expected reclamation behaviour  such that non-compliant implementations of lazy reclamation are detected.  The way Test2406 is implemented also covers this assertion.
column14: Install an SBB with 'activity' as the only convergence name variable selected. Fire an event on Activity Foo. In an event handler method, detach from Foo activity such that the SBB's attachment count is zero. Fire an initial event for the SBB on Foo, and check that  the event is not delivered to the previous SBB object.

column8: A non-SLEE originated logical cascading removal method invocation is initiated by an SBB to remove an SBB entity tree by invoking the remove method on an SBB local object, or invoking one of the remove methods on a ChildRelation object.
A SLEE originated invocation consists of all the transactional method invocations invoked directly by the SLEE within the same transaction on either a single SBB object or a single SBB entity.
Each SLEE originated invocation must include at least one SLEE originated mandatory transactional method invocation.
Life Cycle Only.

The possible SLEE originated method invocations within a SLEE originated invocation of this type are as follows:  1) at least one mandatory txnal life cycle method invocations, followed by 2) at most one sbbExceptionThrown method invocation.
Within a SLEE originated invocation, these methods must be invoked on the same SBB object, also known as the target SBB object of the SLEE originated invocation.
If the target SBB object enters the Ready state, then the target SBB entity of the SLEE originated invocation is the SBB entity represented by the SBB object.
Remove only:
The possible SLEE originated method invocations within a SLEE originated invocation of this type are as follows: 1) a SLEE originated logical cascading removal method invocation.

The target SBB entity of a Remove Only SLEE originated invocation is the root SBB entity of the SBB entity tree being removed. There is no target SBB object in a Remove Only SLEE originated invocation.

The possible SLEE originated method invocations within a SLEE originated invocation of this type (Op Only) are as follows: 1) zero or more mandatory txnal life cycle method invocations followed by 2) an invocation of either an event handler method, a sbbServiceDeactivated method, or a sbbRolledBack method, followed by 3) zero or more mandatory txnal life cycle method invocations, followed by 4) at most one sbbExceptionThrown method invocation.
Within a SLEE originated invocation, these methods must be invoked on the same SBB object, also known as the target SBB object of the SLEE originated invocation.
If the SBB object enters the Ready state, then the target SBB entity of the SLEE originated invocation is the SBB entity represented by the SBB object.
The SBB object must enter the Ready state for the SLEE to invoke its event handler method, or its sbbRolledBack method .
column14: From event handler call getSbbContext().getActivities(), which will only return a value if the SBB is in the Ready state.  Could also roll the SBB back in the event handler and check getActivities() in sbbRolledBack() before returning test pass/fail.

column8: The possible SLEE originated method invocations within a SLEE originated invocation of this type (Op Remove) are as follows: zero or more mandatory transactional lifecycle method invocations, followed by, 2) an invocation of either an event handler method, a sbbServiceDeactivated method, or a sbbRolledBack method, followed by 3) zero or more mandatory transactional lifecycle method invocations, followed by 4) at most one sbbExceptionThrown method invocation, followed by 5) a logical cascading removal method invocation.

Within a SLEE originated invocation, these methods, except the logical cascading removal method invocation, must be invoked on the same SBB object, also known as the target SBB object of the SLEE originated invocation. The SBB object must be in the Ready state when its event handler method, its sbbServiceDeactivated method, or its sbbRolledBack method is invoked.
column14: Can't tell the difference between one SBB object and another.

column8: The target SBB entity of a SLEE originated invocation of this type is the SBB entity represented by the target SBB object.  The target SBB entity is always known since the target SBB object must be in the Ready state

The SBB entity tree or SBB entity sub-tree to be removed by the logical cascading removal method invocation within a SLEE originated invocation of this type must be the SBB entity tree or SBB entity sub-tree rooted by the target SBB entity.

If any of the methods (except the sbbExceptionThrown method) invoked on the target SBB object of a SLEE originated invocation returns by throwing a RuntimeException, then the SLEE invokes the sbbExceptionThrown method of the target SBB object of the transaction within the same transaction.
column14: Fire event.  Send TXN ID from event handler to TCK.  Throw RuntimeException.  In sbbExceptionThrown send TXN ID to the TCK.  Verify that the TXN IDs match.

column8: There is at most one sbbExceptionThrown method invocation in each of the above SLEE originated invocation types since the SLEE will move the target SBB object of the SLEE originated invocation to the Does Not Exist state after invoking the sbbExceptionThrown method once on the SBB object. The SLEE will not invoke any other methods on the SBB object once it enters the Does Not Exist state.

column8: If an invoked method is a non-transactional method, then the invoked method does not run in the same transaction as the SLEE originated mandatory transactional method invocation. The invoked method runs with an unspecified transaction context (see Section ).

column8: Each transaction initiated by the SLEE must be described by a valid SLEE originated invocation sequence.
A SLEE originated invocation sequence is a ordered sequence of one or more SLEE originated invocations.
The SLEE completes a SLEE originated invocation in the ordered sequence before beginning the next SLEE originated invocation in the ordered sequence.
column14: E.g. fire an event, verify that it is completely processed before the sbb is removed (activity end event?)  Not possible to test accurately - even if the TCK is sent a message immediately before the event returns there's no guarantee that in a non-compliant system that the sbb will not be removed before the 'return' kicks in.

column8: A valid sequence contains at most one Op Only or Op And Remove SLEE originated invocation. This means that each transaction may contain at most one event handler, sbbServiceDeactivated, or sbbRolledBack method invocation.

A valid sequence contains at most one Op Only or Op And Remove SLEE originated invocation. This means that each transaction may contain at most one event handler, sbbServiceDeactivated, or sbbRolledBack method invocation.

If the sequence contains a Remove Only or an Op And Remove SLEE originated invocation, then the Remove Only or an Op And Remove SLEE originated invocation must be the last SLEE originated invocation in the sequence.

If the sequence contains one Op Only and one Remove Only SLEE originated invocations, then the target SBB object invoked by the Op Only SLEE originated invocation must enter the Ready state or be in the Ready state, and the target SBB entity of the Remove Only SLEE originated invocation must be the root SBB entity of the target SBB entity invoked by the Op Only SLEE originated invocation.
A valid sequence does not contain SLEE originated method invocations on more than one SBB object that enters the Ready state from the Pooled state or is already in the Ready state.
There are two types of transactional resource:
JTA transactional resources: A JTA transactional resourcue is a XA resource as defined by JTA.

Non-JTA transactional resource: A non-JTA transactional resource supports transactions in a resource specific manner, such as a JDBC 2.0 driver that does not implement javax.transaction.xa.XAResource.
The SLEE specification does not require a SLEE to support JTA transactional resources.
A SLEE may integrate with EJB 2.0 containers to support transaction context propagation when methods on EJB interfaces are invoked within a transaction.
When more than one event is fired on a particular Activity Context within the same transaction, the order of receipt of the events must be the order of the firing of events.
column14: Fire initial event on SBB.  Within initial event handler fire two events on the same ACI.  In the first custom handler set CMP field, in the second handler verify that this field has been set and return pass/fail accordingly.

column8: The SBB Developer must be aware that combining transactional and non-transactional resources in the same transaction may violate properties of the transactional programming model such as the atomicity guarantee.
There are two cases for the behaviour of the SLEE when an invocation throws an exception.  These cases are: Non-SLEE originated method invocation, SLEE originated method invocation.
If a non-SLEE originated invocation returns by throwing a checked exception, then the following occurs:
The state of the transaction is unaffected.
column10: Check that the txn is not marked for rollback.
column14: In test 894 check the rollback status before throwing the exception and afterwards and make sure the rollback status doesn't change.

column8: The checked exception is propagated to the caller.  It is expected that the caller will have appropriate logic to handle the exception.
column14: Throw checked exception from SbbLocalObject, and verify that the exception is propagated.

column8: If a non-SLEE originated invocation returns by throwing a RuntimeException, then:
The transaction is marked for rollback.
column14: Call SbbLocalObject method from SBB event handler, throw RuntimeException in the SbbLocalObject method, check that the TXN is marked for rollback.

column8: The sbbExceptionThrown callback method is invoked as described in Section 6.11.
column14: Call SbbLocalObject method from SBB event handler, throw RuntimeException in the SbbLocalObject method, verify that sbbExceptionThrown() is called.

column8: The sbbRolledBack method is only invoked on the SBB entity invoked by the highest level SLEE originated invocation.
column14: Call an SbbLocalObject method on a child SBB from the parent's SBB event handler, throw RuntimeException in the SbbLocalObject method, verify that sbbRolledBack() is called on the parent SBB.

column8: If the RuntimeException propagates  to the highest level (i.e. the SLEE originated invocation returns by throwing an unchecked exception) the SLEE originated invocation exception handling method is initiated.
column14: Throw RuntimeException from SbbLocalObject method, catch it and rethrow it. Verify that sbbRolledBack() is called (one of the chain of events that happens when RuntimeException is thrown from a SLEE-invoked method.)

column8: If all the method invocations belonging to a SLEE originated invocation return without throwing an exception or by throwing only checked exceptions, then the following occurs:
If the transaction is not marked for rollback, then: The transaction is moved to the Committing state.
column10: Sbbs have no view of this tx state transition.

column8: If the transaction cannot be committed, then the transaction is rolled back and if the SLEE originated mehod invocation has a target SBB entity, the SLEE eventually invokes the sbbRolledBack method in a new transaction on another SBB object that represents the same SBB entity as described in Section 6.11.1.
column10: Sbbs have no standard means to influence whether or not the tx is rolled back after the tx is in the committing state.

column8: If the transaction is marked for rollback, then the transaction is rolled back and if the SLEE originated method invocation has a target SBB entity, the SLEE eventually invokes the sbbRolledBack method in a new txn on another SBB object that represents the same SBB entity as described in Section 6.11.1.
column14: In event handler method send message to the test containing TXN ID.  Mark TXN for rollback.  In sbbRolledBack() method send TXN ID to the test, and have the test determine test pass/failure.

column8: If a SLEE originated invocation returns by throwing a RuntimeException, then the following occurs:
The transaction is marked for rollback.
column14: On the child in first event handler: send message back to the test containing the TXN object ID. Call parentSbbLocalObject.setSomeValue(42).  Throw RuntimeException.

column8: The sbbExceptionThrown callback method is invoked as described in Section 6.11.
column14: Verify that sbbExceptionThrown() is executed by sending value to the test.

column8: The SBB object that was invoked is discarded.
The transaction is eventually rolled back.
column14: In second event handler parent should check value set via its local object interface by the child and ensure that it's at default and send message to the test containing whether that test passed or not.

column8: If the SLEE originated method invocation has a target SBB entity, and the SLEE was not invoking the sbbRolledBack method on the target SBB entity, the SLEE eventually invokes the sbbRolledBack method in a new txn on another SBB object that represents the same SBB entity as described in section 6.11.1.
column14: Send message back to the test containing TXN object ID used in sbbRolledBack() method.  In the test verify that the objects are different.

column8: If a transaction that includes a SLEE originated logical cascading removal method invocation does not commit (because the sbbRemove method of one of SBBs invoked returns by throwing a RuntimeException or marks the transaction for roll back, or for some other reasons like optimistic concurrency control conflicts, deadlocks, or internal SLEE problems), the SLEE is expected to forcefully remove the SBB entity tree that would have been removed by the SLEE originated logical cascading removal method invocation after the SLEE has invoked the sbbRolledBack callback corresponding to the transaction that did not commit.

When a transaction rolls back, the SLEE should deliver a transaction rolled back callback for each SLEE originated invocation in the transaction that has a target SBB entity. The SLEE delivers each of these transacation rolled back callbacks by invoking the sbbRolledBack method in a new transaction on another SBB object that represents the corresponding target SBB entity.
A Profile Table contains zero or more Profiles that conform to the same schema.
Profile Specifications, Profile Tables and Profiles participate in the following relationships:
Profile Specifications and Profile Tables: 1-to-many
column14: Install a profile specification, then create many (3) profile tables in it, then check that they all exist.

column8: Profile Tables and Profiles: 1-to-many
column14: Create a profile table, then create many (3) profiles in it, then list the table's contents to check that they all exist.

column8: Profiles and Profiles: many-to-many
column12: Profile references many profiles; Many profiles reference profile
column13: Profile references many profiles; Many profiles reference profile
column14: Create profiles X,A and B. Add references to A and B from X, and references to X from A and B. Commit the changes.

column8: Each Profile may reference another Profile or itself. The SLEE does not impose any restrictions on the Profile references.
Address Profile Tables and Services: 1-to-many
column10: Check that service A and service B can both be installed if they share the same address profile table.

column8: Resource Info Profile Tables and Services: 1-to-many
column10: Check that service A and service B can both be installed if they share the same resource info profile table.

column8: The Administrator must assign a globally unique name to each Profile Table, known as the Profile Table name.
column10: The uniqueness constraint is covered by the test for 3867

column8: The Java type for the Profile Table names is java.lang.String.

A Profile Table name cannot be null or zero-length, and may only contain letter or digit characters as defined by java.lang.Character.isLetter and java.lang.Character.isDigit. Additionally, any other character in the Unicode range 0x0020-0x007e may be included in a Profile Table name, except for the  /  character (Unicode 0x002f).
column10: The null and zero-length cases are covered by other assertions.
column14: Try to create a profile table with a name containing all the chosen valid characters, and check that no exception is thrown. For each chosen invalid character, try to create a profile table with name consisting of only that character, and check that the InvalidArgumentException is thrown.

column8: Each Profile within a Profile Table must have a unique name within the Profile Table.
This name is known as the Profile name.
The Java type for Profile names is java.lang.String.

A Profile name cannot be null or zero-length, and may only contain letter or digit characters as defined by java.lang.Character.isLetter and java.lang.Character.isDigit. Additionally, any other character in the Unicode range 0x0020-0x007e may be included in a Profile name.
column10: The null and zero-length cases are covered by assertions 3897 and 3899.
column14: Try to create a profile with a name containing all the chosen valid characters, and check that no exception is thrown. For each chosen invalid character, try to create a profile with name consisting of only that character, and check that the InvalidArgumentException is thrown.

column8: The Profile Table name and Profile name together uniquely identify a Profile within the SLEE.  This is known as the Profile identifier.
column10: The uniqueness of the profile table/profile name is covered by test 3900 which attempts to create duplicates

column8: The Java type that encapsulates Profile identifiers is the ProfileID class (see Section 10.2).
A Profile Table can also be identified by an Address object.  The address plan of this Address object is SLEE_PROFILE_TABLE and the address string contains the Profile Table's name.

A Profile can also be identified by an Address object.  The address plan of this Address object is SLEE_PROFILE and the address string contains the Profile identifier encoded as "profile_table_name/profile_name".
column14: Create a profile table, then add profiles A and B to it. Attach an SBB to B's activity, then edit and commit B. In the ProfileUpdatedEvent event handler method, check the address plan, and check that the address contains the profile table's name and profile's name.

column14: Install a profile spec which contains a profile management abstract class which sets an attribute to a non-null value. Create a new table, and check that the default profile has been initialised (ie check that the attribute is set to the non-null value).

column8: In addition, an Admistrator can update the default Profile of the Profile Table through the SLEE's management interface.

When an Administrator adds a Profile to the Profile Table, the SLEE copies the persistent state of the default Profile to the new Profile.  The default Profile of a Profile Table provides the initial values for the attributes of new Profiles of the same Profile Table.

column13: Value: the initial default value; the current deafult value.

column8: Each Profile Table has an associated Activity.
The Java object that encapsulates the associated Activity is a ProfileTableActivity object.
The SLEE fires the following types of events on a ProfileTableActivity object:
After a Profile is added to a Profile Table, the SLEE fires a Profile Added Event on the Profile Table's Activity.
column14: Create a profile table, attach an SBB to its activity, then add a profile to it. Check that a ProfileAddedEvent event is delivered to the SBB. In the event handler method, check that the ACI represents the profile table's activity.

column8: After a Profile has been updated, the SLEE fires a Profile Updated Event on the Profile Table s Activity.
column14: Create a profile table, attach an SBB to its activity, then add a profile to the table. Make some changes to the profile, and commit the changes. Check that a ProfileUpdatedEvent is fired for the profile. In the event handler method, check that the ACI represents the profile table's activity.

column8: After a Profile is removed from a Profile Table, the SLEE fires and delivers a Profile Removed Event on the Profile Table's Activity.
column14: Create a profile table, attach an SBB to its activity, add a profile to it, then remove the profile from it. Check that a ProfileRemovedEvent event is delivered to the SBB. In the event handler method, check that the ACI represents the profile table's activity.

column8: These events are also known as Profile Table Events.

The SLEE invokes the event handler methods for these ProfileTable Events within a transaction and these event handler methods can act on the Profile Table additions, updates, and deletions  with full access to the runtime environment.

In the ProfileAddedEvent handler, check that getRollbackOnly() does not throw a TransactionRequiredLocalException. Make some changes to the profile, and commit the changes. In the ProfileRemovedEvent handler, check that getRollbackOnly() does not throw a TransactionRequiredLocalException.

In the case of a Profile Removed Event, the SLEE is the event producer and the default address provided by the SLEE for the Profile Removed Event is the address returned by this method.

The getProfile method returns the Profile identifier of the Profile removed from the Profile Table. The Profile identifier may or may not identify an existing Profile in the Profile Table. For example, the Profile identifier may not identifies a new Profile in the Profile Table if a new Profile has been added with the same Profile identifier after the previous Profile with same Profile identifier was removed but before the SLEE delivers the event.

Each Profile Specification includes:

A Profile CMP interface: This interface defines the schema of the Profile Table, i.e. it defines the attributes of each Profile in the Profile Table.  The SBB Developer declares each attribute using a pair of get and set accessor methods in this interface.
column10: Covered by all profile tests that utilise a ProfileCMP interface

column8: A Profile Management interface: This interface declares the methods that are made available to management clients.
column10: Covered by all profile tests that utilise a ProfileManagement interface

column8: These methods may include methods declared in the Profile CMP interface and additional SBB Developer declared management methods that interfact and manipulate the attributes of a Profile that conforms to this Profile Specification.
column10: Covered by all profile the tests ProfileManagementTest and ProfileCMPMethodHidingTest

column8: A Profile Management abstract class.  This abstract class implements the Profile CMP interface, the Profile Management interface, and the ProfileManagement interface.
column10: Covered by all profile tests that utilise a Profile Management abstract class

column8: The SLEE implements the get and set accessor methods of the Profile CMP interface in a derived class of the abstract class when the Profile Specification is deployed.
column10: This assertion is covered by all tests that use Profile CMP accessor methods via the profile management interface

column8: A Profile Specification deployment descriptor element.
There are three ways to view a Profile Specification:
SBB Developer's SBB object view: this view consists only of a read-only view of the attributes of the Profile.  These attributes are defined in the Profile CMP interface.
The SBB object is only permitted to invoke the get accessor methods of the Profile CMP interface.
SBB Developer's management view.  This view of a Profile Specification defines the Profile Specification specific methods that are made visible to management client ...
... and may optionally provide implementations of the Profile Management object life cycle callback methods that are invoked by the SLEE.
If the SBB Developer defines a Profile Management interface, then the Profile Management interface defines the Profile Specification specific methods that are made visible to management clients.

If the SBB Developer does not define a Profile Management interface, then the Profile Management interface is the Profile CMP interface.  Hence, all get and set accessor methods  declared in the Profile CMP interface are made visible to management clients.
column10: Many tests use the CMP get and set accessors of profiles that do not have a ProfileManagement interface defined

column8: The SLEE provides the implementation of these methods (CMP field get and set accessor methods) in a concrete subclass of the Profile Management abstract class.
column10: Covered by all profile management tests that utilize CMP get and set accessors

column8: The SBB Developer must provide the implementation of these methods in the Profile Management abstract class.
If the Profile Management declares any management methods, the SBB Developer must provide a Profile Management abstract class.
The Profile Management class must also implement the life cycle callback methods that are declared in the SLEE specification defined ProfileManagement interface.

Since the management view is dependent on the existence of an SBB object view, the SBB Developer may only define a management view if an SBB object view is defined.  More precisely, a Profile Specification cannot include a Profile Management interface and/or a Profile Management abstract class if it does include a Profile CMP interface.
An Administrator's view of a Profile Specification is the Profile Specification's JMX MBean interface, known as the Profile MBean interface.

The Profile MBean interface is generated by the SLEE when the Profile Specification is deployed from the methods defined in the Profile Management interface if a Profile Management interface is provided or from the Profile CMP interface if a Profile Management interface is not provided.
column10: The first clause is covered by assertion 971.  The second clause is coveredd by many tests that use profiles which do not define a profile management interface

column8: The Profile CMP interface must be declared as public.

CMP fields are defined in the Profile CMP interface by the use of abstract get and set accessor methods with the following design pattern: public abstract <attribute type> get<attribute name>();  public abstract void set<attribute name>(<attribute type> value);
Attribute names must be valid Java identifiers.
column14: Create a Profile CMP interface with attribute name "public".

column8: The first letter of the attribute name in a get and set accessor method must be capitalized, as determined by java.lang.Character.isUpperCase.
Each attribute must have both a get and set accessor method defined, and the corresponding types used in the get and set accessor methods must be the same.
Attribute types must conform to the requirements specified in section 10.13.
Neither get nor set accessor methods are permitted to take a throws clause.
The Profile CMP interface may have super-interfaces, however all super-interfaces are also subject to the rules for definition of Profile CMP interfaces.

While the Profile CMP interface defines both get and set accessor methods, the current SLEE specification does not allow an SBB object to change Profile attribute values using the set accessor methods.  An SBB object that attempts to invoke set accessor methods in the Profile CMP interface should expect to receive a java.lang.UnsupportedOperationException.
column14: Create a profile and fire an event to an SBB.  On receiving the event the SBB should attempt to update the CMP field via the setter method.  Check that the expected SecurityException is thrown

column8: A Profile may reference other Profiles (or itself) if it has attributes whose Java types are ProfileID, or Java types that contain ProfileID objects, such as classes that directly or indirectly contain ProfileID objects or ProfileID arrays.
column12: (A) Target: another profile; self. (B) Reference type: direct ProfileID; indirect ProfileID
column13: (A)  another profile; self. (B) ProfileID; ProfileID[] array
column14: Create profiles X,A and B. Add references to A and B from X in an array, and add references to X from A and B as direct ProfileID attributes. Add a reference from X to X. Commit the changes.

column8: The SLEE does not check that the ProfileID objects in the CMP fields of a Profile refer to Profiles that exist.
column14: Create profiles X and C. Delete profile C. Create a reference from X to C. Commit the changes to X.

column8: The Profile Management interface must be declared as public.
The Profile Management interface may extend the Profile CMP interface.

The Profile Management interface may declare attribute get and set accessor methods.  These methods must be declared in the Profile CMP interface, i.e.the method name, argument and return types must be the same as declared in the Profile CMP interface and must not have a throws clause.
The Profile Management interface may declare management methods.

Management methods may have any name but the name must not be the same as any method defined in the javax.slee.profile.ProfileMBean interface (see Section 10.16.3) or the Profile CMP interface unless these methods are overloaded, i.e. have different input arguments.
Management methods may have any name but the name must not begin with "profile".
Management methods may have any name but the name should not be one of the method names defined in JMX interfaces such as javax.management.DynamicMBean and javax.management.MBeanRegistration.
Method argument and return types must conform to the requirements specified in Section 10.13.
Methods may define an arbitrary throws clause.
The Profile Management interface may have super-interfaces, however all super-interfaces are also subject to the rules for definition of Profile Management interfaces.
The Profile Management abstract class must be declared as public and abstract.
The Profile Management abstract class implements the following interfaces:
It must implement the javax.slee.profile.ProfileManagement interface.
It must implement the Profile CMP interface defined in the Profile Specification, but must not implement any of the get and set accessor methods defined in the Profile CMP interface.

If the Profile Specification defines a Profile Management interface, the Profile Management abstract class must implement the Profile Manangement interface.  All  management methods defined in the Profile Management interface must be implemented in the Profile Management abstract class.
These method implementations must be public, and cannot be static, abstract, or final.

A Profile Management abstract class that does not implement a Profile Management interface is limited to implementing Profile life cycle callback methods only as the SLEE implements the CMP field accessor methods declared in the Profile CMP interface.
The Profile Management abstract class must have a public constructor that takes no arguments.
The profileInitialize, profileLoad, profileStore and profileVerify methods, defined in the ProfileManagement interface, must be implemented in the Profile Managament abstract class.
These method implementations must be public, and cannot be static, abstract, or final.
The isProfileDirty and markProfileDirty and isProfileValid methods must not be implemented as they are implemented by the SLEE.  These three methods are implemented by the SLEE at deployment time.
The Profile Management abstract class may have super-classes, however all super-classes are also subject to the rules for definition of Profile Management abstract classes.
A developer implemented method of the Profile Management abstract class must propagate any javax.slee.ReadOnlyProfileException it catches to the caller.
A Profile Management object can be either one of the following objects:
An object that implements the Profile Management abstract class.

If the Profile Specification defines a Profile Management abstract class, then the SLEE extends the Profile Management abstract class and implements the abstract methods of the Profile Management abstract class.  An instance of the derived concrete implementation class of the Profile Management abstract class is a Profile Management object.

If the Profile Specification does not define a Profile Management abstract class, then the SLEE implements a class that implements methods defined in both the Profile CMP interface and the ProfileManagement interface.  An instance of this class is a Profile Managment object.

The profileInitialize method can be used to initialize the initial persistent state of a Profile. It can be assumed that the Profile has been created before this method is invoked.

This method is called once only when the default Profile (see Section 10.1.4) of a Profile Table is first created.  The method is not called each time a Profile is added to a Profile Table since the initial persistent state of the Profile is copied from the default Profile of the same Profile Table.

column8: An SBB Profile Management object is dirty if its CMP fields have been modified or, if its CMP fields will be modified when it synchronizes the transient state held in its instance variables with its CMP fields (when the profileStore method is invoked).
The dirty flag of a Profile Management object is:
Automatically set to true whenever a CMP field of the Profile Management object is successfully updated.
Explicitly set to true when the markProfileDirty method is invoked on the Profile Management object.
Automatically set to false when the state cached in the Profile Management object is successfully committed.
The isProfileDirty and markProfile dirty methods run in the same transaction context as the calling management method.

The SBB Developer hides a CMP field accessor method by declaring a Profile Management interface that does not extend the Profile CMP interface and only includes in the Profile Management interface the CMP field accessor methods that should be visible.
Accessor method renaming builds on CMP field accessor method hiding.  In addition to hiding the CMP field accessor methods, the SBB Developer provides a substitute method with a different name.
The SBB Developer provides the implementation of the substitute method in the Profile Management abstract class.
Typically, the substitute method delegates to the hidden CMP field accessor method.
All attributes, method parameters, and return types that are used in Profile CMP interfaces and Profile Management interfaces must be legal RMI-IIOP types.

For easy management using event the most basic of management clients, or human Administrators, it is also recommended that the types used in the methods of the Profile CMP interface or the Profile Management interfaces that are exposed as Profile MBean interfaces be restricted to the following:
Java primitive types, or the equivalent object wrappers.
java.lang.String
One-dimensional arrays of the above types.
Each service may optionally reference the two following Profile Tables:
A Resource Info Profile Table.  This table contains the provisioned data that should be passed to resource adaptor entities when the Service is in the Active state.
An Address Profile Table.  This table contains provisioned addresses that may cause new root SBB entities of the Service to be instantiated (see Section 10.14.2).

Since this version of the SLEE specification does not specify the contract between the resource adaptor entities and the SLEE, when and how the information is passed between the SLEE and resource adaptor entities is implementation dependent.

Conceptually, when a Service enters the active state, the SLEE passes all the information contained in the Service's Resource Info Profile Table to the resource adaptor entities instantiated in the SLEE.  When a Service's Resource Info Profile Table changes, the SLEE should notify the resource adaptor entities of this change.
A Resource Info Profile has a single info attribute.  The Java type of this attribute is java.lang.String.
column10: Specified in the CMP interface

column8: Two Services may specify incompatible or conflicting information in their Resource Info Profile Table.  This version of the SLEE specification does not specify how the SLEE or the resource adaptors should handle this situation.
A Service may optionally reference an Address Profile Table.  Any Profile Table that meets the following requirements can be a Service's Address Profile Table:
An Address Profile Table must include an address attribute.  The Java type of this attribute is an Address array.
Hence, the Profile CMP interface of the Profile Specification of the Profile Table must include the following methods: public Address[] getAddresses(), public void setAddresses(Address[] addresses).

The addresses attribute must be indexed and unique.  This is specified using a profile-index element in the Profile Specification's deployment descriptor (see example in Section 10.14.2.2).  In addition, the unique attribute of the profile-index element must be "True".  It is used to enforce the uniqueness of addresses stored in the Address Profile Table.
The SLEE specification defines a standard Address Profile specification.  The standard Profile Specification has the required single addresses attribute.
At Profile Specification deployment time, the SLEE implements the following classes for the Profile Specification:
The SLEE implements a class that implements the Profile CMP interface.  This class is known as the Profile CMP implementation class and is for the SBB object view of the Profile Specification.

column8: The Profile MBean class may use javax.slee.management.ManagementException to report errors to the management client when an attempt to access or update persistent CMP fields fails due to a system-level problem.
All Profile MBean classes implement the javax.slee.ProfileMBean interface.  The ProfileMBean interface defines the methods that support a transational life cycle for the Profile MBean objects.
The implementation of this method (editProfile) should start a new transaction for the editing session, or perform the equivalent function.

If a system-level failure is encountered during the execution of this method or a concurrent edit of the same Profile is attempted on a SLEE implementation that does not support concurrent edits (see Section 10.18.2), the implementation should throw a javax.slee.management.ManagementException to report the exceptional situation to the Administrator.
If the Profile MBean object is already in the read-write state when this method is invoked, this method has no further effect and returns silently.

The implementation of this method (commitProfile) must invoke the profileVerify method of the Profile Management object that caches the persistent state of the Profile, and only commit the changes if the profileVerify method returns without throwing an exception.

If the profileVerify method throws a javax.slee.ProfileVerificationException, the commit attempt should fail, the exception is forwarded back to the management client, and the Profile MBean object must remain in the read-write state.

Check by using different attributes check that the commit is successful when no exception is thrown and that commitProfile() correctly throws a ProfileVerificationException and no commit is performedd

column8: The implementation of this method must also verify that the constraints specified by the Profile Specification's deployment descriptor, such as the uniqueness constraints placed on indexed attributes.  The SLEE verifies these constraints after it invokes the profileVerify method of the ProfileManagement object.
If any constraint is violated, then this method throws a javax.slee.profile.ProfileVerificationException, the commit attempt fails, and the Profile MBean object must remain in the read-write state.

If a commit succeeds, the Profile MBean object should move to the read-only state.  The SLEE must also fire a Profile Updated Event if a Profile has been updated (see Section 10.4.2).  The dirty flag in the Profile Management object must also be set to false upon a successful commit.

column8: If a commit fails due to a system-level failure, the implementation of this method should throw a javax.slee.management.ManagementException to report the exceptional situation to the management client.  The Profile MBean object should continue to remain in the read-write state.

The execution of the commitProfile method (and profileVerify callback methods of the Profile Management object) must run in the same transaction context as that begun by the editProfile invocation that initiated the editing session.  The transaction should only be committed if the commitProfile method returns successfully, i.e. without throwing an exception.

The Administrator invokes the restoreProfile method if the Administrator wishes to discard changes made to the Profile Management object that caches the persistent state of a Profile.

The implementation of this method rolls back any changes that have been made to the Profile Management object since the Profile MBean object entered the read-write state and moves the Profile MBean object to the read-only state.

The execution of this method must begin in the same transaction context as that begun by the editProfile invocation that intiated the editing session, but must roll back the transaction before returning.

The isProfileWriteable method returns true if the Profile MBean object is in the read-write state, or false if in the read-only state.

The isProfileDirty method returns true if the Profile MBean object is in the read-write state and the dirty flag of the Profile Management object object that caches persistent state of the Profile returns true.  This method returns false under any other situation.
A Profile Specification must be deployed before Profile Tables of the Profile Specification can be created.  A Profile cannot exist before the Profile Table that it belongs to is created.
When a Profile Table is created, the default Profile is created and initialized.
The default Profile is deleted when the Profile Table is deleted.

column8: A Profile MBean object must be registered with the SLEE's JMX MBean Server in order to be accessible to management clients.

The JAIN SLEE specification does not dictate when a Profile MBean object or a Profile Management object must be created or destroyed.  However, an appropriate Profile MBean object must be registered with the MBean server when the JMX Object Name of a Profile is requested via the ProfileProvisioningMBean and may be deregistered when the closeProfile method is invoked on the Profile MBean object.

column8: When a Profile MBean object is created, the Profile MBean object must portray a read-write view to management clients.
column14: On a newly created ProfileMBean check that the profile is in read only state by calling the isProfileWritable() method

column8: Alternatively, when the editProfile method is invoked on a Profile MBean object, the Profile MBean object also shifts to the read-write state.

If the restoreProfile method is invoked on the Profile MBean object, any changes that have been made to the Profile Management object that caches the persistent state of the Profile since the Profile MBean object entered the read-write state must be discarded.

If instead the commitProfile method is invoked on the Profile MBean object, the profileVerify callback method is invoked on the Profile Management object that caches the persistent data of the Profile.

If the verification callback returns without throwing an exception and the Profile MBean object passes additional SLEE implemented verification (such as checking for uniqueness of "unique" indexed attributes), the changes made to the Profile Management object are committed and the Profile MBean object moves to the read-only state.  If an exception is thrown by the verification callback, the Profile MBean object remains in the read-write state.
If an exception is thrown by the verification callback, the Profile MBean object remains in the read-write state.
The SLEE may invoke the profileLoad and profileStore methods at any time to synchronize the transient state held in the Profile Management object with the persistent state cached in CMP fields.

If the Profile MBean object is in the read-write state, then the SLEE invokes the profileLoad and profileStore methods with the same transaction context as management methods of the Profile Management objects.

Profile MBean objects do not always have to be registered with the SLEE's MBean Server.  The Administrator can only access a Profile after it invokes the createProfile, getProfile and getDefaultProfile methods of the ProfileProvisioningMBean interface (see Section 13.9).

Each of these methods returns a suitable JMX Object Name for the appropriate Profile.  However, before returning the Object Name from one of these methods, the SLEE must ensure that the appropriate Profile exists and the Profile MBean object that represents the Profile is registered with the MBean server.

column8: When the Administrator creates a new Profile, the Administrator has read-write access to a Profile MBean object, equivalent to invoking editProfile on the Profile MBean object. The initial attribute values of the new Profile MBean object are obtained from the default Profile. The SLEE will try to add the new Profile to the Profile Table only after the Administrator invokes the commitProfile method on the Profile MBean object. This allows the Profile MBean object and the SLEE to verify the contents of new Profile before adding the Profile to the Profile Table.
